dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE OPEN on a montage of varied ETHNIC COMMUNITIES from th different boroughs of NEW YORK CITY. CARS, PEDESTRIANS an CITY SOUNDS intersect and blend with the beat of the musi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A door opens and a pair of BEAT UP CONVERSE KICKS step outside. They belong to NATASHA KINGSLEY, 17, beautiful, an enormous afro. The sun on her face makes her smile.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I don’t care what anyone says... New York’s the best city in the world. While on her phone, Natasha struts by local shops: a Pakistani restaurant with a line of CAB DRIVERS out the d an Optimo cigar store, and a Taiwanese electronics store.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It's a place where 8.5 million people coexist--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Passengers rush down the stairs as she climbs up to the “ train station at 167th. Thick Jamaican accents blend with Spanish and Haitian French. Natasha listens, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It’s a lot to take in. A train whizzes by revealing her on the platform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Natasha emerges from the “A” train at 175th. BEVERLY “BEV RAMIREZ, 17, Dominican, waits anxiously. They’re late. Th girls rush off arm-in-arm.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But with a little luck you can find a best friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A number of SENIORS stand in line. “Congratulations Class 2019 - The Bronx High School of Science” is on the marque Natasha and Bev squeeze in as the line moves forward.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It's a city where hard work and determination are constants against unknown variables in the equation for success--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the ornate auditorium, velvet seats are filled wit FAMILY and FRIENDS. The STUDENTS, now dressed in graduati caps and gowns, enter single file to Pomp and Circumstanc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PRINCIPAL and FACULTY on stage. Natasha’s poised at the e Like a runner in blocks. Her name is barely called when s Marches across the stage to claim her diploma.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ...And dreams can become tangible when you reach out and grab them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Caribbean-American Graduation Party in full swing. Ligh strung from corner posts. A Jamaican flag stretched acros the fence. Jerk chicken and fish on the grill. Dishes wit curried goat, oxtails, plantains, peas and rice. ADULTS i traditional garb. And TEENS on a makeshift dance floor. F Natasha and Bev in the middle. Dancing. Laughing.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t have wanted this perfect night to happen anywhere but here: the city I’m proud to call my home. On Tasha’s face, smiling as she looks at the night sky fi with fireworks and stars. Twinkling. It’s truly magical.

dialogues.speaker: MATCH CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. NATASHA’S APARTMENT - DAY - REALITY A NASA STAR MAP on a wall. Pull out to reveal Tasha in a small apartment, moving boxes everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Or at least a city I used to call my home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind her, a LITTLE HAND pulls back the bright blue curt separating the room. REVEAL: PETER, 9 years old, chocolat with dreadlocks and a grin from ear to ear.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Unless a cataclysmic blunder is corrected, the odds of me actually graduating with my friends are declining. Rapidly. Peter whips the curtain closed, unseen.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You see, I’m an illegal immigrant and my family is scheduled for deportation. Tomorrow. WHOOSH - Natasha pulls back the curtain. Peter is jugglin soccer ball on his knees in the next room. ZOOM in on Pet

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Look, Tasha! Peter fumbles with the ball. The ball gets away from him, bumping into a neat stack of Natasha’s books.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: How many times do I have to tell you not to practice in our room?! Peter picks his nose and examines what he dug up. NATASHA (CONT’D) Ewww! Peter, stop it. You’1l never get friends that way.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Doesn't matter. I’1l make new friends in Jamaica! Natasha sighs heavily, the weight of her family’s struggl on her shoulders. A key RATTLES in the lock. MRS. KINGSLEY, Natasha’s 40-ish, world-weary mother, drag from work wearing a waitress uniform.  4. She sees a kitchen full of dirty dishes. NOTE: Mr. And Mr Kingsley both speak with a heavy Jamaican accent and dial

dialogues.speaker: MRS. KINGSLEY
dialogues.text: Tasha. How many times I’m gonna have to tell you to clean the dishes before I come home?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: You haven’t even closed the door yet and you're already yelling--

dialogues.speaker: MRS. KINGSLEY
dialogues.text: It's not enough to pick up dirty plates at work? I come home to pick up dirty plates too?!

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Mom, please. I’11 do it now. Mrs. Kingsley heads to her bedroom. Natasha goes into the kitchen, draws soapy water and washes the dishes. Mrs. Kingsley emerges from the bedroom wearing a bathrobe. NATASHA (CONT’D) You work too much.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. KINGSLEY
dialogues.text: Somebody gotta keep a roof over all our heads, child. Who else gonna do it? REVEAL: MR. KINGSLEY, late 40s, small frame, sad eyes, sitting in front of the TV. We haven’t noticed him until Mr. Kingsley watches as LAWRENCE OLIVIER performs a monol from “Othello” on screen. He studies him intently.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My father’s an actor. At least, that’s why he came to America. But that’s not exactly how it’s worked out. PULL OUT: Mr. Kingsley performs the scene along with Oliv He’s in perfect sync with the actor on TV.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It’s his fault we’re in this mess. Natasha finishes the dishes. Mrs. Kingsley makes eggs.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. KINGSLEY
dialogues.text: You want breakfast?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have an appointment at the Immigration Office this morning. It's at eight.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. KINGSLEY
dialogues.text: You don’t think it’s time for you to give up now, Tasha? You don’t think what you’re doing is futile? Natasha grabs a piece of fruit off the table.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: There’s still time, Mommy. We have today. And I’m going to use every last second. Can’t give up yet.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Don’t think of it as giving up. Think of it as embracing destiny.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: I’d rather make my own. Peter smiles, turns up Sister Nancy’s “Bam Bam” and sings along. Natasha rolls her eyes. She grabs her headphones a her Physics textbook.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (re: textbook) We leaving, Tasha. You don’t have to turn in homework. We’re free!

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: I’ll be back later.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. KINGSLEY
dialogues.text: You have a lot to finish here. I still see open boxes in your room.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Mom, I really gotta go. Natasha heads for the door, determined. She takes a deep breath, opens the door and steps outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Natasha stops at a specific spot on the platform and chec her phone: 6:55 AM. She looks down the track-- nothing.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Ugh. Come on. Not today.  INT. DANIEL’S APARTMENT - BEDROOM - DAY DANIEL JAE HO BAE, 17, stands in front of a mirror sizing himself up in the suit he’s wearing. He adjusts his red t clearly uncomfortable in what he’s wearing.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Today's the day my whole life has led up to... From outside the room, his mother, MIN SOO, 40s, calls ou

dialogues.speaker: MIN SOO, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (in Korean) Daniel! I’m making you a special breakfast. Hurry down.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The day of my college interview for Yale.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Coming!

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The day that decides my future. Behind him, shelves full of the world’s greatest poets: Shakespeare, Shelly, Frost, Poe, Plath, Angelou, Hughes.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Normally I’d write a two-page poem about something of this magnitude. At least a haiku. But today, my anxiety’s holding me hostage. Daniel grabs his writer’s notebook, throws it into his satchel. Takes one final glance at himself.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Because I need every brain cell focused on nailing this interview. Daniel takes one final glance at himself, then exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daniel’s mother steams frozen dumplings. Daniel pours a b of Cap’n Crunch. She shakes her head disapprovingly. Min speaks with a heavy Korean accent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too much sugar. You need a sharp mind today. She grabs the bowl of cereal, replaces it with a plate of dumplings, and pours the dry cereal back into the box.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I’m pretty sure I inherited my mother’s anxiety...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG MIN SOO and YOUNG DAE HYN, nervous and afraid, pres their paperwork to the CUSTOMS AGENT.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Which started the day she uprooted her whole life in Korea to come to America. For most immigrants, moving to a foreign country is an act of faith. What if you can’t adapt? What if you’re not welcomed? What if you lose all sense of your identity and culture?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FAMILY and FRIENDS crowd the apartment. Min Soo holds her first born, CHARLIE, as ONE-YEAR-OLD DANIEL crawls toward various objects: a stethoscope, pen, basketball, etc. Eac object represents a career or “fate.” THIS IS A KOREAN DOLJANCHI or “DOL” where the child “chooses their destiny

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So when my brother and I were born, she gave us both an American name and a Korean name. So we would know where we were from. And where we were going. The family cheers as Young Daniel nears the stethoscope, grabs the PEN instead to his parents’ dismay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Min Soo interrogates her son between his bites of breakfa

dialogues.speaker: MIN SOO
dialogues.text: How’s your grade in math? You don’t like math.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: B plus. But the rest are A’s.

dialogues.speaker: MIN SOO
dialogues.text: Why no A in math yet, Daniel? Aigo! It's time you get serious... (then, in Korean) Don’t be like your brother. Right as she says this, Daniel’s brother, CHARLIE, 19, wa into the kitchen. Pretends he doesn’t hear this, but his resentful demeanor gives him away.

dialogues.speaker: MIN SOO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I made mandu.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Awww. Daniel’s “special breakfast.” I‘ll pass. Charlie strokes Daniel’s hair. Daniel slaps his hand away

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My brother, Charlie, is an asshole. Charlie grabs the box of Cap’n Crunch, then pours cereal milk into a bowl and sits. He chomps loudly with each bit

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He’s been at home the past semester because he failed too many classes at BU. An epic screw up that my parents can’t accept.

dialogues.speaker: MIN SOO
dialogues.text: Close your mouth when you eat. Charlie ignores her then SLURPS the remaining milk from t bowl. He stands, looks down at Daniel.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Good luck with your day, little brother. Charlie tries to touch Daniel’s hair again and is batted away. CHARLIE (CONT’D) Wouldn’t want to disappoint Mommy and Daddy if you don’t get into an Ivy. Charlie exits, leaving his dirty bowl on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should hate Charlie, but these days, I mostly feel sorry for him.

dialogues.speaker: MIN SOO
dialogues.text: I just don’t understand what happened to your brother. Why he can’t behave, like you.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Umma, give him a break. Daniel finishes the last of the dumplings. Grabs his plat and hand washes it in the sink. Min Soo looks over her son, eyes honing in on his bun.

dialogues.speaker: MIN SOO
dialogues.text: You cut your hair before the interview. Daniel groans, but Min Soo is not having it.

dialogues.speaker: MIN SOO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Too long. You look like a girl.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: They let girls into Yale, too. Min Soo scolds him with her eyes, then hands him a money pouch with deposit slips.

dialogues.speaker: MIN SOO
dialogues.text: Appa forgot this. You bring it to him. After you get a hair cut. Daniel takes the pouch. Kisses his Mom on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Alright, Umma. I’1l get it cut. (off her skeptical look) I promise. Daniel grabs his bag and heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daniel makes his way through his busy Queens neighborhood passing a slew of restaurants, bars and vendors, etc., al written in Korean.  10.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Natasha frantically charges through the MULTI-CULTURAL RAINBOW of IMMIGRANTS. Heads over to the RECEPTIONIST. Sweating and short of breath.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Natasha Kingsley for Karen Whitney. The Receptionist checks her appointment sheet, and shakes head.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: You’re too late. You’1l have to call the main USCIS line and make a new appointment.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: No, you don’t understand. I can’t reschedule!

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. You’ll have to call the main line. The Receptionist shrugs and looks down, dismissing Natash Natasha starts to panic.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: I don’t have time for that. This is an emergency. The trains were delayed. (getting emotional) Just-- could you please call Ms. Whitney? She told me to come back.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Your appointment was for 8 AM. It is now 8:15. She’s seeing another--

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Please. Just call her. Now! Natasha’s now hysterical voice rings through the receptio area. The other applicants stare in her direction.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I guess ‘desperation’ translates into every language. The Receptionist nods at a SECURITY GUARD standing by the door. He sets his jaw and turns toward Natasha.  11. But before he can reach her, another door opens. A tall, thin, brown-skinned man beckons Natasha: LESTER BARNES, 4

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: (to the Receptionist) It's alright, Mary. I’1ll take her. INT. USCIS - LESTER BARNES’S OFFICE - MINUTES LATER Natasha sits in front of an immaculately kept desk. Turns Lester enters with a RED FILE in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: My name is Lester Barnes.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Hi, I’'m-- He holds up a hand to silence her.

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: Everything I need to know is in this file. Do yourself a favor and stay quiet while I read it. Natasha falls silent. Reaches across his desk and pockets of his business cards. After a beat, Lester finally looks LESTER (CONT’D) Why are you here?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Karen--Ms. Whitney--told me to come back. She said maybe there was something--

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: Yeah, well Karen’s new. Your family’s last appeal was rejected. The deportation stands as is. You and your family will have to leave tomorrow. He closes the file and pushes a box of tissues toward her anticipation of her tears. Natasha shakes it off.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I didn't cry when my father told us about the deportation orders. I’m not going to start crying now. Natasha gathers her things. Heads for the door. But she s with her hand on the knob, swallows her pride. Turns arou  12.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: So there’s really nothing you can do to help me? He taps the closed file with his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: Your dad’s DUI--

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Is his problem. Why do I have to pay for his mistake?

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: You’re still here illegally. Natasha nods, on the verge of tears. She heads for the do LESTER (CONT’D) I’ve been to your country. I’ve been to Jamaica. He smiles at the memory as Natasha turns back to him. LESTER (CONT’D) I had a nice time. Everything is irie there, man. You'll be alright. Natasha glares at Lester.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Where did you go?

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: Negril. Very nice place.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Did you leave the hotel grounds?

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: I wanted to but my--

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: But your wife didn’t want to because was she scared, right?

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: No, it’s just--  13.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: You listened to Bob Marley, and a bartender got you some pot and someone told you what irie means, and now you think you know something. That is not a country. That is a resort. He holds up his hands, defending himself. NATASHA (CONT’D) Don’t tell me I'll be alright. I don’t know that place. I’ve been here since I was eight years old. Now it’s my senior year. I should be worrying about the same things my friends are-- like prom and graduation. But instead I’m worrying about being shipped to a country that’s totally foreign to me. This is my home! Natasha’s tears finally pour out. Mr. Barnes slides the tissue box closer. She takes a handful, then heads to the door--

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: Wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daniel leans against a street light, checking his phone. JUMPS as someone WHISTLES loudly in his ear. He turns--

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: What the--? Reveal OMAR HASSABALA, 19, Middle Eastern, raised on Hip

dialogues.speaker: OMAR
dialogues.text: I thought you were going to wait until right before the meeting to put the stick up your ass.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Don’t be mad because I’m going to be part of the one percent. Omar checks out Daniel’s suit, laughing.

dialogues.speaker: OMAR
dialogues.text: You look like a Lebanese insurance salesman.  14.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: You’re supposed to be making me feel better about going to Yale.

dialogues.speaker: OMAR
dialogues.text: That's what I’m doing. Easing your impending sense of doom with the use of comedy. It’s a known tactic.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Well, try something else.

dialogues.speaker: OMAR
dialogues.text: You could just be like me and not go. How about that?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Unlike you, I actually care about what my parents think. And anyway, the interview’s today. Too late to back out now. Omar shrugs and leads the way down the subway stairs.

dialogues.speaker: OMAR
dialogues.text: You’re supposed to wear black to a funeral by the way. Not gray. Daniel playfully hits Omar and they descend into the subw

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tasha stares at a business card and dials the number on i WOMAN answers the line.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Mr. Fitzgerald's office.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Hi, I'd like to make an appointment with Mr. Fitzgerald as soon as possible, please.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Who am I speaking with?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Natasha Kingsley.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Hi, Natasha. What issue can I help you with?  15. Tasha hesitates, afraid to say the words aloud. Silence. WOMAN (V.O., CONT’D) Hello, ma’am? He does have a slot at 11 A.M. Can you tell me your issue?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: I’m an illegal alien. Tasha’s heart races, afraid. We see the giant imposing federal buildings surrounding her as she sits on the step

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daniel and Omar sit in the congested subway car. Daniel l at his reflection in the shiny metal subway door. Turns s can see his ponytail.

dialogues.speaker: OMAR
dialogues.text: You should just let me cut your hair. I brought my pocket knife.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: No, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: OMAR
dialogues.text: Your mom’s right, you gotta lose the man bun. You don’t want to be a virgin forever.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: You know, if this interviewer’s so smart, he’ll recognize a cool haircut when he sees one.

dialogues.speaker: OMAR
dialogues.text: Or at least a desperate attempt at cool. The train COMES TO A SCREECHING HALT. The friends, along the other PASSENGERS, wait patiently for a beat. THEN, a super CHIPPER VOICE over the loudspeaker...

dialogues.speaker: CONDUCTOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Looks like we got a slight delay, folks. Track work on 68th. A collective GROAN from the passengers.

dialogues.speaker: CONDUCTOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I know you’re all panicking, thinking that you’re late... (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: CONDUCTOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: but look on the bright side, maybe the universe is telling you something. GROANS again.

dialogues.speaker: OMAR
dialogues.text: I knew we should’ve taken the express.

dialogues.speaker: CONDUCTOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Happens to me all the time. Something goes off in my routine -- boom...must be the Universe. It’s full of unexpected blessings.

dialogues.speaker: PASSENGER
dialogues.text: Usually the nut jobs are on the train, not driving it.

dialogues.speaker: CONDUCTOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Deli screws up my order. Universe... Maybe I shouldn’t be eatin’ deli sandwiches all the time. Guess what? I switched it up and lost twenty pounds. Thank you, universe. The train does a collective eye roll in complete disbelie

dialogues.speaker: OMAR
dialogues.text: This guy needs a drug test. The Conductor goes quiet. After a few more seconds in the dark, the train finally pulls into Grand Central.

dialogues.speaker: CONDUCTOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We've reached the end of the line. Ladies and gentlemen, back to your regularly scheduled program. Passengers breathe a sigh of relief as the DOORS OPEN.

dialogues.speaker: CONDUCTOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This train is now out of service. But remember: The universe is talking... So slow down and listen. Omar rises from his seat and heads to the exit. Daniel SI beat, taking in the conductor’s words.  17.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daniel and Omar emerge from the train to find themselves the main concourse of Grand Central Station.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: How much time you got before work?

dialogues.speaker: OMAR
dialogues.text: ‘Bout an hour. Why? Daniel looks to the walkways situated behind on the massi windows overlooking the terminal.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: It's been a while since we went up. Today’s the perfect day. Daniel starts to make his way through the diverse crowd o people rushing to their trains.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on! Omar follows after Daniel, almost losing sight of him in pedestrian traffic. EXT. TASHA’S HIGH SCHOOL - DAY Tasha stands outside the fence of her school. Fighting te

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It’s still hard for me to believe that after today I may never see this school again. INSERT SHOTS: She and Bev sitting down at the courtyard outside laughing, walking the hallways, gossiping, etc. BACK TO SCENE: The real Bev walks up.

dialogues.speaker: BEV
dialogues.text: Please tell me you have good news.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Bev’s the closest thing I have to a sister. The longest time we’ve ever been apart is two weeks.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: I wish. I was late, so they wouldn’t let me see Ms. Whitney.  18.

dialogues.speaker: BEV
dialogues.text: (desperate) So what does that mean? You're leaving?! Isn’t there someone else you can talk to? Tasha pulls out the card.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: I’ve got one last shot. This guy Jeremy Fitzgerald. He’s supposed to be some kind of immigration fixer.

dialogues.speaker: BEV
dialogues.text: Oh my God! That’s amazing! (then) Wait, why are you here? He should be “fixing” this! Go!

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: I’ve got a few hours before my appointment with him.

dialogues.speaker: BEV
dialogues.text: You should come to Chem Lab and mess with Mr. Busby. He’s got on his polyester mom jeans again.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: My appointment’s uptown. I don’t want to rush. I’m just gonna hit the record store. Kill some time. The bell rings.

dialogues.speaker: BEV
dialogues.text: Text me the address. I’'1l skip out after my test and we can grab lunch.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Perfect. They share a look. Bev heads back inside. Tasha puts her headphones on and queues up Major Lazer album. We hear GE FREE and see it carry her worries away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daniel and Omar chill behind the oversized windows of the main terminal, overlooking the bustling crowd below. All Grand Central’s architectural glory in perfect view.  19.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: My life’s gonna go one of two ways after today. If I don’t get into Yale, it’ll be Charlie all over again. And if I do...white jackets and picket fences from now until eternity.

dialogues.speaker: OMAR
dialogues.text: The American Dream.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Even if I win, I lose. What kind of future is that?

dialogues.speaker: OMAR
dialogues.text: If losing means you're rich, sign me up.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I just wish I could do something about it. Daniel sighs. He turns over and lies face up on the walkw

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There's gotta be something more to it all than this. His gaze catches the gigantic mural of the Universe paint on the ceiling of the terminal.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You ever notice that before?

dialogues.speaker: OMAR
dialogues.text: Notice what? Off Daniel’s look, Omar joins him on the ground, eyes up. majesty of the mural is on full display. Several constellations are recognizable.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: It’s a sign.

dialogues.speaker: OMAR
dialogues.text: Oh, see now, you’re just making stuff up. We’ve passed this thing a million times.  20.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Yeah, but have you ever seen it? It's like the conductor said on the train, maybe the universe is trying to tell me something.

dialogues.speaker: OMAR
dialogues.text: Yep. “You’re losing it, bro.”

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I’m serious, Omar. Of all the days we've been here, today is the day that I notice the most amazing thing in all of Grand Central? It’s not a coincidence.

dialogues.speaker: OMAR
dialogues.text: Okay, then let’s suppose this conductor was right...the universe is talking. What’s it saying? Daniel sits up, looking out into the main terminal. Peopl shuffle back through the concourse. He looks around, eyei everything in sight...nothing. A train pulls in.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I don’t know yet.

dialogues.speaker: OMAR
dialogues.text: Go figure. Daniel plops down on the ground, then... He spots HER in crowd. A young, Black woman with an enormous, curly AFRO almost-as-enormous PINK HEADPHONES. It’s Natasha. Her eyes are closed as she sways to her music, in complet bliss. Omar notices Daniel’s gaze and shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: OMAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now what? (looking out) It’s just a cute girl, Daniel. Relax. (double take) Okay, she’s real cute. Natasha walks underneath them, moving her backpack to one shoulder REVEALING the back of her jacket. It reads: CARP DIEM. Daniel’s completely struck.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Look at her jacket! Carpé Diem.  21.

dialogues.speaker: OMAR
dialogues.text: Carpé wha--

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Carpé Diem... “Seize the Day.” (off Omar, unfazed) It's gotta be a sign. C’mon on! Daniel drags Omar off in the direction he last saw Natash

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daniel’s eyes light up as he follows Natasha from a dista

dialogues.speaker: OMAR
dialogues.text: This is stalker-ish, you know.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: No, it’s not. I’m maintaining a non- creepy, half-block distance. Tasha enters a record store. GALAXY RECORDS. Daniel stops his tracks. Stares at Omar.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (re: the store’s sign) You gotta be shitting me! This is definitely a Sign.

dialogues.speaker: OMAR
dialogues.text: Okay. Definitely ironic. I'll give you that... And she is cute...

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I want to know where this leads.

dialogues.speaker: OMAR,
dialogues.text: Hopefully not to jail. But if it does, don’t call me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Natasha enters the record store, smiling anyway.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: If today were not today, I would spend all day here. Tasha enters the “Rap” section. Then she sees a COUPLE ma out next to a poster of Madonna's Like a Virgin. She frow  22.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Ugh. Of all the people to run into, on today of all days, why did I have to run into my ex? Why isn’t he in school? This is my place! These two are ROB, 17, and KELLY, 17. Kelly snakes her ha out and SNATCHES A RECORD. She slips it between their bod and into her bulky jacket. Tasha shakes her head, appalle

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: She’s just going to steal that? Tasha turns to find Daniel standing right behind her.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: I know! Doesn’t anybody work here? Can’t they see what’s happening?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Shouldn't we say something? Tasha shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: (re: Rob and Kelly) No. I know them.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Sticky Fingers is your friend?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: She’s my boyfriend’s girlfriend.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: How does that work exactly?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: I mean ex-boyfriend. He cheated on me. With her, actually.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: TMI, Tasha. I didn’t need to volunteer that tidbit toa stranger.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Great pair. (beat, then) We should tell someone.  23.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: No way! If I say something, it’s going to look like I’m jealous and messing with them.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Are you?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: That's kind of a personal question, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: We were having a moment.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Were we? Rob pauses from making out, looks up to see Tasha and Dan staring at them from a distance. NATASHA (CONT’D) Jesus Christ bleeding on a popsicle stick...he saw me! Rob gives Tasha a half-smile and a small wave. Tasha turn her back to him, facing Daniel instead. NATASHA (CONT’D) Oh God...is he coming over here?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Yup.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Maybe we should make out or something. Like spies do in the movies. Daniel blushes. Hard. Tasha notes his blush and leans back. NATASHA (CONT’D) I’m not serious. Obviously. Rob approaches them.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Hey...

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Why are you and your girlfriend stealing things?  24. Rob holds his hands up and takes a step back.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Whoa, dude. Keep your voice down.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: This is an independent record store. That means it’s family owned. You’re stealing from real people. Do you know how hard it is for small businesses to survive when people like you just take stuff? Tasha spots an EMPLOYEE approach Kelly.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Uh...don’t look now, but I think your girlfriend just got busted. Rob looks over at Kelly. EMPLOYEE #2 has now joined them. shoves his hands into his pockets and walk-runs toward th front door.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Rob! But Rob doesn’t stop. He bolts out, leaving her behind.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Damn, that was cold. Kelly hands Employee Prince’s “Purple Rain” from under he jacket. The employee snatches the record.

dialogues.speaker: EMPLOYEE
dialogues.text: Come back in here again and I will call the cops. Kelly nods, then exits quickly.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Well, at least she has good taste.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Yeah, I guess if you’re going to steal a Prince record, might as well be his best one, right?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I don’t know if that’s his best one. Solid top three, for sure.  25.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Tell me, in your opinion, what is his best album?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Controversy. My mom used to play that song all the time when I was a kid. Tasha smiles, impressed. Daniel stares at her, googly-eye Grinning.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Listen, Red Tie--

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Daniel. My name is Daniel. He sticks out his hand for a shake. Tasha shakes it. He h it a beat too long. A moment passes between them.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: It was nice meeting you, Daniel. But I really have to go--

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Well, maybe I can walk you--

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: No, I’m good. Take care, Daniel. Tasha puts her headphones back on and starts walking for door quickly, leaving Daniel standing there kicking himse

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Natasha walks out into the crowd and spots Rob and Kelly ahead. Kelly cries as Rob gives his best half-ass explanation. Natasha moves past them unnoticed. Daniel, ear to his phone, eyes Tasha in the distance as h follows her.

dialogues.speaker: OMAR, (V.O., ON THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you just get her number in the record store?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Because she wouldn’t give it to me.

dialogues.speaker: OMAR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I think that’s clearly a sign, don’t you?  26.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: But it’s not like she totally blew me off. She was nice. I’m telling you, there was a spark there.

dialogues.speaker: OMAR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And following her like a serial killer is going to reignite that?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I’m not following her. She just happens to be going my way. Natasha stops at the crosswalk ahead of Daniel.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, shit, I’m getting close. She'd definitely think I was stalking her if she turned around now.

dialogues.speaker: OMAR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Well, then whatever you do, don’t -- Daniel hangs up in a panic. Strains, deciding whether to or say something as he approaches. Daniel takes a deep breath. He’s about to veer off when-- A WHITE BMW flies down the avenue. The light turns red ag and Natasha STEPS OFF THE CURB, not paying attention. SHE’S ABOUT TO GET HIT when Daniel YANKS her backwards by arm. They fall backwards onto the sidewalk. Natasha lands half on top of Daniel as her phone and headphones CRASH AGAINST THE PAVEMENT. She looks down at spider webs cracking across her phone’s screen.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: What. The. Hell?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: That guy almost killed me. She looks up the block as the BMW sits on the side of the road with its blinkers on. Then looks to her headphones. NATASHA (CONT’D) Do you know how long I’ve had these? Natasha cradles her broken headphones in her hands.  27.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I‘1l buy you another pair. She shakes her head “no.”

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s the least I can do. Tasha finally looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: You already saved my life.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: You wouldn't have died. A little maimed, maybe. Natasha stares back at him, unfazed. Her eyes fill with tears.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: I’m having just the worst day. (a beat; realizing) Wait. Were you following me?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Man, I knew you would think that.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: You just happened to be right behind me?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Maybe it was meant to be. Natasha exhales deep.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: I’m just gonna ignore that. Thanks for your help.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: At least tell me your name.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Natasha.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Nice name.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: So glad you approve. Daniel stares at her, inquisitive.  28. NATASHA (CONT’D) Why are you staring at me? Daniel blushes again. Natasha stares at his face. His hai

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Observable Fact: The man-bun pushes him from cute to kind of sexy.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Now you're staring. Tasha blushes, then clears her throat.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Why are you wearing a suit?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I have an interview later. Wanna go get something to eat?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Yale. Alumni admission interview. I applied Early Decision. Natasha shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: No, I meant why do you want to get something to eat?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I’m hungry?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Hmmm. I’m not.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Coffee then? Or tea or soda or bottled water?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Why? Daniel shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Why not? Besides, I’m pretty sure you owe me your life since I just saved it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daniel and Tasha sit across from each other at a Tasha checks the time on her phone: 10:00 A.M.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Wait. Why aren’t you in school?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: (lying) . ; I have a doctor’s appointment in an hour. Tasha sips her coffee. Silence. 29. cozy table. Daniel fidgets nervously. Blows on his cappuccino so hard little foam flies up on his face. Tasha chuckles. She then looks at his satchel, suddenly curious. NATASHA (CONT’D) What do you keep in there?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Not much. My notebook. I carry it pretty much everywhere I go. Daniel pulls out a black notebook. Flips through Tasha glances at it. Sees the handwritten blocks

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: You're not a poet, are you?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: No, I just kind of dabble in it. For fun. Next year I‘ll be pre-med. Self-conscious, Daniel quickly puts the notebook bag. Tasha notices, leans in.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: (flirting) So what are your poems about? Love?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Among other things. Yes, love.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: I don’t believe in love.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Well it exists, whether you believe in it or not. it quickly. of text. back in his  He laughs. 30.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Oh really? Can you prove it?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Thousands of love songs. Poetry. The institution of marriage.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Words on paper. Never mind the fact that eating large amounts of chocolate has the same effect on you as falling in love.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I love chocolate. Tasha laughs, too.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You say it’s just words on paper, but you have to admit all those people are feeling something.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: People just want to believe. Otherwise they would have to admit that life is just a random series of good and bad things that happen until one day, you die.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: And you're okay with believing that life has no meaning?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: I’m okay believing in the things that science can make sense of. If love made sense, more than forty- eight percent of all marriages would make it.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Are your parents married?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Yeah, but if that’s what marriage is, it’s not for me.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: So no fate, no magic, no meant-to- be for you?  31.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Boy, please. Quantum Physics is all the magic I need.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I don’t think I’ve ever met anyone so charmingly deluded.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: And you find that appealing?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I find it interesting. (beat, then) What if I told you I could get you to fall in love with me scientifically? Without chocolate.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: I would scoff. A lot.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I’m serious. It’s a thing. The New York Times had an article about it. Researchers put a bunch of couples in a lab and had them ask each other a bunch of intimate questions. Also, they had to stare into each other’s eyes for four minutes without talking.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: That sounds ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: And yet, it’s a real thing. Daniel and Natasha stand in line at the register, waiting pay. Daniel has his phone out.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There are thirty-six questions. How about I choose ten randomly.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Knock yourself out. It’s never going to happen.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Great. Question number one, what are the five key ingredients to falling in love?  32.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: I don’t believe in love, remember? (off his look) Okay. Fine--mutual self-interest and socio-economic compatibility.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Do you even have a soul?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: No such thing. He laughs at Tasha as if she’s kidding, but she’s not.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Well, my ingredients are friendship and chemistry.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: (patronizing) But, of course. Sorry, go on.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I think some kind of moral compass is important. And let’s see... Physical attraction and the X factor.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: What’s the X factor?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Don’t worry. We already have it. He smiles charmingly. A strand of Daniel’s hair falls int his face. He puts it behind his ear.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: This quiz isn’t going to make me fall in love with you, Red Tie.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: It's Daniel. And give me today.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Can’t. I have a doctor’s appointment.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Okay. I’1l walk you there.  33.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tasha leads the way, darting in and out of pedestrian traffic, as Daniel struggles to keep up.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: So, where are we headed?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: I am heading to my appointment on the east side and you are, apparently, tagging along with me.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Yep. And while we’re walking... Daniel takes out his phone.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You ready for more questions?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: You are relentless.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Persistent. Now, question number two: Would you like to be famous and how?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: You first.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I'd be a famous poet laureate.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: And you'd be broke.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Broke with money But rich with words.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: What does a poet laureate even do?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Offers wise and poetic counsel. Tasha makes some gagging sounds.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Be cynical all you want, but many a life has been saved by poetry.  34.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: You’re not joking, are you?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: What about you? What kind of fame do you want?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Easy. I'd be a benevolent dictator. Daniel laughs.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: You know, all dictators think they’re benevolent. Even the ones holding machetes.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Nope. Pure benevolence from me. I would decide what was good for everyone and do it.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: But what if what’s good for one person is not good for another?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Can’t please everyone. As my poet laureate, you could comfort the loser with a good poem.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Touché. She glances at him, feeling a surprising connection. They stop at a corner, waiting for the light to change. We enter a MUSICAL MONTAGE of them walking through the ci as they get to know each other. The urban sounds melt awa a wistful piece of music takes over. Natasha soaks up the city she’s about to say goodbye to and Daniel continues t try and win her full attention. Daniel pulls out his phone again and begins scrolling thr questions. Natasha watches him.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Tell me again why you're wearing a suit? (off his groan) Come on, I get to ask questions too.  35.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Yale. Interview.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Really. Are you nervous?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I’m fine. My parents have only been prepping me for this my entire life.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: They're immigrants, huh?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Yup.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Mine too. Do you even want to go to Yale?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: It doesn’t matter what I want.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: It's your life.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: And what about yours? You sound like you’ve got it all figured out.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: I’m going to be a data scientist. (off his look) Data scientists analyze data and recommend actions based on the results. They’re also very well- paid.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: That’s so practical. Have you always known what you wanted to be?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Well, it wasn’t predestined. I did research on growing fields in the sciences. I chose one, and tada.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: So, it’s not something you're passionate about? She shrugs.  36.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: I don’t want to have to rely on anyone or wind up working night shifts just to make ends meet. I can’t live off of passion any more that I could off of love. They climb some steps and walk along an elevated walkway.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: It's a long life to spend doing something you’re only ‘meh’ about.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: It's a long life to spend chasing dreams that aren’t real. Do you know how many people want to be actors or writers or rock stars? A lot. Ninety-nine percent of them won't make it. Zero point nine percent of those left will barely make any money doing it. Only the last zero point one percent make it big. Everybody else just wastes their lives trying to be them.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Are you secretly my father?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Ha ha. Look, when you’re a happy doctor making lots of money, you’ll thank him that you didn’t become a starving artist dreaming pointlessly about making it big. Tasha notices the disappointed look on Daniel's face. NATASHA (CONT’D) Wait, you’re not serious about the poetry thing, are you?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Honestly? If I had my way, yeah. This track I’m on is too predictable. Yale. Medical school. Residency. Marriage. Children. Retirement. Nursing home. Funeral home. Cemetery. (then) People have big, beautiful brains! We invent things that fly. We are capable of anything under the sun. We are capable of big lives. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How great would it be if we all went after the things we actually believed in? Their eyes meet. She’s inspired by his passion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tasha stops in front of a glass high-rise building on lst Ave. Its corporate design contrasts with the illustrious building on the opposite side of the street. She looks up the building, knowing it may be her last hope.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: So, this is me.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I can wait for you out here.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Daniel. You have an interview and I have this... thing. This is where we say goodbye. Daniel falls silent for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Am I going to see you again?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: There are eight and a half million people in this city. Unless we just happen to run into one another, again the odds aren’t in our favor.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Let’s do that over. Do you want to see me again? A beat. Neither one moves... Daniel doesn’t wait for her reply.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Never mind. I can see that you're a little stressed by this appointment...like I was before I saw you. Let’s try something. Daniel raises his arms laterally, away from his body.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Lift your arms like this.  38. Natasha obliges, reluctantly. Daniel inches closer and cl to her, arms out.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Ummm. What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: They say that something as simple as a hug can do wonders for stress.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Do they?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Mmmhmm, it’s science. Daniel stands face to face with Natasha, both of their ar outstretched, almost wrapping around one another. But the don’t touch.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If this is goodbye, then let this hug be my parting gift. Okay? Tasha pulls him in. He holds her tight. Tasha lets her he drop onto his shoulder and her body relax into his arms.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Go, Tasha. Time to go.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Let go, Daniel. Let her go. Daniel releases her. Tasha pulls back, smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Nice meeting you, Daniel. Good luck with your interview. Daniel nods. Tasha heads to the building.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: (calling after her) You really don’t think we’ll see each other again, do you? She turns back to Daniel.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: It’s highly unlikely.  39.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: The odds were that we'd never meet in the first place, you know. But we did. Daniel looks to the sky. Cracks a smile.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Why are you smiling?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Because I know this isn’t our last time together. Daniel’s naiveté upsets Tasha. Tears gather in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Daniel. Tasha turns away from him so that he can’t see her face. walks through the large glass doors of the building. INT. BUILDING - HALLWAY/FITZGERALD’S OFFICE - DAY Tasha opens a door to find a partially built office. The walls are half painted and bare bulbs hang from the ceili Sawdust and paint splotches cover the tarped floor. A woman, HANNAH, 30s, sits behind the desk. She smiles as Tasha approaches.

dialogues.speaker: HANNAH
dialogues.text: You must be Natasha. Tasha nods.

dialogues.speaker: HANNAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, I have some bad news. Tasha’s stomach folds in on itself.

dialogues.speaker: HANNAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jeremy-- Attorney Fitzgerald, was in a car accident an hour ago. Hannah continues the story as Tasha listens.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Turns out that BMW that almost hit me had already done its fair share of damage...  40.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JEREMY FITZGERALD crosses the street.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My attorney-to-be was crossing the street, and without his own personal Daniel to save him... BOOM. The WHITE BMW cruises through a stoplight and KNOCK JEREMY TO THE GROUND.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: A drunk and distraught insurance actuary hit him. Jeremy crawls to the side of the street as other PEDESTRI help him up and call 911.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hannah continues talking to Tasha.

dialogues.speaker: HANNAH
dialogues.text: His wife says he’s fine, just a few bruises. But he won’t be back until later this afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: But that might be too late--

dialogues.speaker: HANNAH
dialogues.text: Didn't you hear what I said? He was hit by a car. He’ll see you later. Hannah pushes a sheaf of forms over to Tasha.

dialogues.speaker: HANNAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: In the meantime, I need you to fill out these forms. Hannah points Tasha to an adjacent desk. She fills most o quickly. Then pauses at the back page. The prompt: “PLEAS GIVE A FULL ACCOUNTING OF YOUR TIME IN THE UNITED STATES.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I have no idea what to write. So I give the facts: my family traveled to America on a tourist visa and we have not left the country since. We have committed no crimes, except for my dad’s DUI.  41. Tasha jots this down quickly, then hands the papers back Hannah. Hannah flips through it, then stops on the back p

dialogues.speaker: HANNAH
dialogues.text: You need more here.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: HANNAH
dialogues.text: What does America mean to you? Why do you want to stay?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Is that really--

dialogues.speaker: HANNAH
dialogues.text: Anything Jeremy can use to humanize you will help. Tasha sits back down. The phone rings as she stares at th blank page. Struggling. Hannah talks as Tasha tries to fo A second phone line rings as Tasha works on the forms. Ha hangs up and grabs the second line before it can ring twi

dialogues.speaker: HANNAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh my God, Jeremy. Are you alright? As Jeremy responds, a relieved smile crosses Hannah’s fac

dialogues.speaker: HANNAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank goodness, I was worried sick! (beat) Yes, of course. I'll see you later. Hannah hangs up the phone and comes back into the recepti area, aglow with relief.

dialogues.speaker: HANNAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He’s alright.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: That’s great. Hannah takes the forms from Tasha and reads through them.

dialogues.speaker: HANNAH
dialogues.text: I’ve seen lots of cases like this-- you'll be okay.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: You think so?  42.

dialogues.speaker: HANNAH
dialogues.text: Jeremy never loses. I’m not supposed to say this...but just know there’s hope. Tasha exhales, a burden lifted. INT. FITZGERALD’S BUILDING - LOBBY - MOMENTS LATER Tasha exits the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S8.)
dialogues.text: Hey! Tasha turns to the voice. It’s Bev.

dialogues.speaker: BEV
dialogues.text: How'd it go?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Good. I think.

dialogues.speaker: BEV
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Well, it’s not official yet, but... there may be something other than resigned dread in my future. Bev squeals, then squeezes Tasha tight in a hug.

dialogues.speaker: BEV
dialogues.text: That's amazing! Are you going to call your parents?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: And say what? A man who I don’t know sent me to see another man I don’t know. Then a paralegal, who is not a lawyer, whom I also don’t know, says everything will be all right. What’s the use in getting all our hopes up?

dialogues.speaker: BEV
dialogues.text: Hope seems like a good substitute to whatever you’ve been feeling. Tasha smiles.  43.

dialogues.speaker: BEV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t tell me. Can you use the scientific method on it? Can you observe it, measure it, experiment with it and repeat your experiments?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: You cannot. They both laugh.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: You know I can only take so much positivity. (beat) But there is something measurable I have to tell you. I met a boy...

dialogues.speaker: BEV
dialogues.text: Um, what? When? Deets please!

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Okay, so I saw Rob up at Second Coming this morning... As Tasha tells her story, INSERT FLASHBACK SHOTS of Danie enhanced by her memory and favorable shades of lighting: - Beautifully backlit after he saved Tasha’s life. - Getting foam on his nose at the coffee spot. - Lovingly looking at her as he says “goodbye.”

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And as I gave Bev the full Daniel rundown, it hit me...

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: I didn’t even get his full name!

dialogues.speaker: BEV
dialogues.text: What a fail.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: I know! I should’ve gotten his number. Tasha looks down to her phone. It’s 11:35. NATASHA (CONT’D) I mean, what if this immigration nonsense does resolve itself? How will I find him again?

dialogues.speaker: BEV
dialogues.text: Maybe he waited for you. Wouldn't that be romantic? Bev looks around the lobby, searching.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Don’t be ridiculous. He had an interview. He’s not still here. In spite of herself, Tasha starts to look around the lobb too. Hopeful. But she can’t find him. Her shoulders slump

dialogues.speaker: BEV
dialogues.text: Ha! You’re disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: And how is that funny?

dialogues.speaker: BEV
dialogues.text: Because you really like this dude! I’ve never seen you like this.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: (still searching the lobby) Please. It’s not like I think we were meant to be or anything ridiculous like that...just saying, it would've been nice-- Tasha finally sees Daniel. He’s crossing the lobby, makin beeline for her. She covers her excitement.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Hey. What happened to your interview?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: No hug. No “I’m so happy to see you"?

dialogues.speaker: BEV
dialogues.text: You clearly don’t know Tasha that well. Hi, I’m Bev. You must be "the boy.” Tasha cuts her eyes at Bev, deadly.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Actually it’s Daniel.  45.

dialogues.speaker: BEV
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you, Daniel. (to Tasha) Okay. I’m out. Bev hugs Tasha.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: I thought we were having lunch.

dialogues.speaker: BEV
dialogues.text: I think you’ve got other plans. Bev grins from ear to ear as she trots off. She types Tas text: Call me later. PS, pls get the digits this time!!! Tasha turns to a smiling Daniel.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Your interview?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Oh, that old thing? I postponed it.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Are you insane? This is your life we're talking about.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I didn’t burn the building to the ground, ‘Tash. I just moved it until later.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: ‘Tash? We're doing nicknames already?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tasha shivers a little and rubs her hands down her forear from the cold. Daniel takes her jacket and helps her into

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Did you postpone for me?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Absolutely.  46.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: What makes you so sure I’m worth it?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Instinct. How did your thing go?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Fine. I have to come back at 3:30. Daniel looks at his phone: 11:45 AM.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Looks like we have more time together.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Looks that way, huh? The two of them exchange flirty smiles. NATASHA (CONT’D) So, what should we do now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Manhattan skyscrapers have been replaced by small, closely-packed stores with bright awnings. Harlem feels l like a city and more like a neighborhood. Almost everyone black. Tasha and Daniel walk down the street, talking.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Your father owns a black hair care shop called “Black Hair Care”?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Yep. Not the most creative name in the world, I’1l give you that.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Hmm. I guess when you said ‘store,’ that’s not what I was expecting. How'd they get into that?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My family didn’t enter the Black hair care business by chance. A STILL PHOTO OF DANIEL’S FAMILY COMES TO LIFE.  47.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: When Dae Hyun and Min Soo moved to New York, Dae Hyun’s cousin gave them a loan to open a Black Hair Care store. A photograph of a Korean plane suddenly moves, the plane lands in New York City. A photo of Dae Hyun’s COUSIN spri into action as he hands Daniel’s parents some cash. A Hai Care Store frozen in time suddenly bustles.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: His cousin had a similar store and it was thriving. As were stores other South Koreans had opened up. A wide shot reveals the cousin in front of a store, he go inside. A dozen other Black Hair Care Stores are alive an thriving on the block.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And South Koreans didn’t dominate the Black hair care industry by chance. In the 1960s wigs made with South Korean hair were insanely popular in the African-American community. Various photographs of BLACK WOMEN come to life. As they down the street, wigs of every style are on display.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: So much so that the South Korean government banned the export of raw hair to ensure South Korean wigs could only be made in South Korea. That combined with the U.S. banning the import of wigs containing Chinese hair effectively solidified South Korea’s dominance in the wig market. The wig business evolved to the more general Black hair care business. Of which South Koreans currently control 60-80%.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: They finally stop in front of his father’s store. Posters BLACK WOMEN in all styles--afros, weaves, braids, etc., a the windows.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So this is it...  48. Daniel turns to Tasha, tugs his tie from side to side nervously.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So, you should know that my dad’s really...

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Daniel. It’s fine. I get it. All parents are embarrassing. Daniel averts his eyes. Tasha reaches out for the door, b he stops her.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Maybe you could just wait out here. Tasha lets the door go, stunned. Daniel reaches for the d

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I‘ll be right back. He sees the hurt in Tasha’s eyes, feels awful.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, can I try that again? Tasha gives him a big smile. Daniel opens the door for Ta

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: After you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bell chimes as they enter. It’s small and crammed with of metal shelves and products. Dae, DAE HYUN, 50s, is bus ringing up a customer at the register.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Well, this is it... You need to go to the bathroom or anything? There's one in the back. Tasha shakes her head. He strangles the pouch with his ha Nervous.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Want to show me around?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Not much to see. First two aisles are for hair. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Shampoo, conditioner, extensions, dyes, lots of chemical things I don’t understand. Aisle three is make-up. Four’s equipment. He glances at his dad, but he’s still busy.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you need something? Tasha touches her hair, suddenly insecure.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I didn’t mean a product. We have a fridge in the back with soda and stuff.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Sure. They walk down the hair dye aisle. Tasha stops in front o some boxes with brightly colored dyes, picks up a pink on

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Pink?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Doesn't seem like your style.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Shows how much you know.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I think you would look beautiful with a giant pink afro.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: The whole thing wouldn’t be pink. Maybe just the ends. He reaches for the box and now they’re both holding it an facing each other in an aisle that only has space for one

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: It would look like strawberry frosting. Daniel pulls a few strands of Tasha’s coils. He smiles. S smiles back. A small moment.  50.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Oh, look. My little brother’s here. Daniel jerks his hand from her hair. They both let go of dye at the same time, and the box clatters to the floor. Charlie saunters down the aisle toward them, eyes filled curiosity and a mischievous glee. Daniel hands the dye back to Tasha.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: What’s up, Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: The sky is up, little brother. (then, re: Tasha) Who is this? Charlie’s eyes are on Tasha. Daniel takes a deep breath a readies himself to say something, but Tasha jumps in.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: I'm Natasha. A friend of your brother's.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Oh, I thought maybe he’d caught a shoplifter. We get a lot of those in a store like this. I’m sure you understand. Tasha’s eyes widen, stunned by his rudeness.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ, Charlie. Daniel angrily takes a step toward his brother, but Tasha grabs his hand, pulling him back. Daniel stops, links his fingers with hers and squeezes. Charlie makes a big show of looking down at their joined hands and then back up at them.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Is this what I think it is? He claps his hands together with a loud smack and does a laughing two-step dance.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This. Is. Great. Yes. You know what this means don’t you? All the heat will be off me. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When the ‘rents find out about this I’‘1l be a boy scout again. Fuck academic probation.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Wow. You’re an asshole. He smiles as if Tasha’s paid him a compliment. NATASHA (CONT’D) (to Daniel) Do your thing and let’s get out of here. She squeezes his hand. They turn away and run right into father. Tasha pulls her hand away, but it’s too late.

dialogues.speaker: DAE
dialogues.text: (in Korean) What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Mom said I had to bring you this.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Want me to help translate for your friend?

dialogues.speaker: DAE
dialogues.text: (to Charlie) I thought you didn’t understand Korean. Charlie shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I get by.

dialogues.speaker: DAE
dialogues.text: (in Korean) Is that why you failed out of school? You only get by? Charlie’s smile lessens. Embarrassment showing.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (to Tasha) Don’t worry, he’s not talking about you. Not yet at least. Dae’s face goes completely blank. He suppresses his anger feigns a smile at Tasha.  52.

dialogues.speaker: DAE
dialogues.text: You want something before you leave? He clasps his hands, half-bends at the waist like he usua does for his customers.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: No, thank you, Mr.--

dialogues.speaker: DAE
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes. You’re a friend of Daniel’s. Take anything you want. He pats at his pockets until he finds his glasses and pee at the bottles on the shelf.

dialogues.speaker: DAE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Not this aisle. Come with me. Natasha and Daniel follow him helplessly while Charlie snickers. Dae finds what he’s looking for one aisle over.

dialogues.speaker: DAE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here. A relaxer for your hair. To make your hair not so big. He pulls a tub from a shelf and hands it to her. Charlie laughs long and loud.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mr.--

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Bae.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Mr. Bae. I don’t need any--

dialogues.speaker: DAE
dialogues.text: Your hair’s too big.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: I like it big.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Better get a different boyfriend. Daniel glares at his brother.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: We're leaving.  53. Daniel practically flings the pouch at his father. Then h reaches for Tasha’s hand and leads her toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Thank you, come again.

dialogues.speaker: CHYRON
dialogues.text: Daniel sighs as he tugs Tasha up the block. She shakes he head. Daniel finally stops, hangs his head.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. Tasha’s giggles turn into all-out laughter. She clutches stomach as Daniel stares at her, unamused.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: I don’t think that could've gone any worse. Racist dad. Racist and sexist older brother. And the store! I mean the ancient posters of those women and your dad offering me a relaxer.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I’m glad you think this is funny.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Come on. Tragedy is funny.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Are we in a tragedy?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Of course. Isn’t that what life is? We all die at the end.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I guess so. He steps closer, takes her hand and places it on his ches

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Seriously. I’m sorry. I’m sorry about my family. I’m sorry about everything, about the whole history of the world and all its racism and the unfairness of all of it.  54.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: What are you even saying? It’s not your fault. You can’t apologize for racism.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I can and I do. Tasha warms to his earnestness.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: I get it. It’s hard to come from some place or someone that you’re not proud of... But you’re not your dad. Or your brother thankfully.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Thank you. (beat) I feel like I need a palate cleanser now. What’s your favorite place to go in the city?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Hmm. There’s so many. But I guess if I had to pick one, I’d say the planetarium.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Really? Never been.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Are you serious? Not even the obligatory fourth grade field trip? Daniel shakes his head. Tasha looks at her phone. NATASHA (CONT’D) Then we have to go. There’s a twelve-thirty show if we leave now, we can make it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daniel and Tasha sit side by side.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: So, you ready for the next question?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Oh boy...are we back to that?  55.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I‘ll take that as a yes. (searches) Alright, here we go. How do you feel about your relationship with your mother and father?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: You first.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Well. You met my dad...it’s complicated. Of course I love him, but you can love someone and still have a not-so-great relationship with them, you know? (shrugs) Sometimes I feel like we’re on opposite sides of a soundproofed, glass wall. We can see each other but we can’t hear each other. The train brakes suddenly and jostles them even closer together. She doesn’t move away.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: And your mom?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Pretty good. She’s kind of like me. She paints.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: So she’s a delusional optimist too?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I guess so. (then) Now your turn. Tasha rolls her eyes. She nods.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I‘1l make it easy on you. You can just give me a thumbs up or thumbs down, okay?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mom? Tasha gives the thumbs up.  56.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Way up?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Let’s not go overboard. I’m seventeen and she’s my mom.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Dad? Tasha gives the thumbs down.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Way down?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: (beat) It’s hard to love someone who doesn’t love you back. Daniel and Tasha fall silent as a STREET MUSICIAN carryin VIOLIN boards the car. She starts to play Prince’s “When Doves Cry.” Daniel nudges Tasha.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: She’s playing Prince. Kind of a coincidence, don’t you think? Tasha rolls her eyes. The Musician is so passionate and the tune is so infectio that an ELDERLY PASSENGER starts to loudly hum along. As song goes on, OTHER PASSENGERS hum as well. Daniel smiles big at Tasha as he joins in.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: You're so goofy. The Musician finishes with a flourish and the car breaks in applause. A true New York subway Moment. The Musician takes a bow.

dialogues.speaker: STREET MUSICIAN
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, if you like what you heard, I do accept tips. Cash, credit or debit. The Musician holds her hat in one hand and an iPhone with card-reading square in the other as passengers head out.  57. Tasha stops, pulls out a dollar and puts it in her hat. Daniel smiles and does the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tasha and Daniel wander through the minimal dark space. Spotlights shine on Meteorites. Natasha runs her hand acr the metal-cold surface of a pockmarked rock and ske close her eyes, fingering the divots. Daniel comes close, watch her. She turns to him, her voice a whisper.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: This rock is 4.5 Billion years old. Almost as old as our solar system. Daniel smiles. NATASHA (CONT’D) Just think about that, before humans ever existed, this object was flying through the universe for billions of years! Daniel pauses, taken aback by her.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: You’re like a kid in a candy store.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Just think, humans have only been around for at most two-hundred- thousand years. This rock has been around for five-thousand times as long as all of human history combined.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: The way you talk about this stuff, you should be pursuing astronomy. Natasha walks off into the darkness of the exhibition spa

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: There’s not a lot of jobs in astronomy. Not like the other sciences. Daniel follows her, pauses in a pool of light.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: But this is what you love. Natasha stands in the darkness, just outside the spotligh  58.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Cliche as it sounds, love doesn’t put food on the table. (then) Isn’t that why you’re going to Yale?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I don’t know how it is with your family, but in mine, my parents have a lot of power. And they've already decided my fate. Daniel walks back into the blackness. Tasha follows him. looks at her watch.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Show’s about to start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The night sky is projected on an ENORMOUS SCREEN. Tasha a Daniel stare up at the stars, transfixed.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The night sky... both beautiful and mysterious. Images of the Milky Way galaxy appear.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But the stars only tell part of the story. You see this denser band of stars? That’s the Milky Way. It's our galaxy. Daniel’s eyes go wide as he takes in the spectacle. Tasha notes his reaction and smiles to herself.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It's big. So big that even at the speed of light it would take 100,000 years to travel across it. And this galaxy of ours contains only about 100 billion stars. The two of them are so caught up that everyone DISAPPEARS around them.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
