dialogues.text: Luckily the Milky Way is not the only galaxy in the Universe. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Many of the stars we see are actually in whole other galaxies very far away. Daniel eyes Tasha’s hand on her lap.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: There are about 170 billion galaxies, comprised of hundreds of billions of individual stars. Natasha’s elbow lightly brushes Daniel’s arm. She notices they exchange a look, both embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: There are more stars in the universe than grains of sand on all of Earth’s beaches combined. Daniel looks down longingly at her hand. Reaches his pink slowly towards hers.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Some may find this vastness, this unending darkness, proof of our insignificance. But I see ita little differently. Daniel’s pinky lightly touches her hand. A pause. Natasha freezes. Daniel withdraws his hand quickly. NEIL DEGRASSE TYSON appears on screen, as if he’s standin the middle of the universe. He’s our narrator.

dialogues.speaker: TYSON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The most astounding fact to me is the knowledge that the atoms that comprise life on earth, the atoms that make up our human bodies, are traceable to the stars. Daniel takes a deep breath, slowly brings his hand toward Natasha’s hand again.

dialogues.speaker: TYSON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Stars that collapsed and then exploded, they became the ingredients for life itself. Daniel’s fingers lightly cover Natasha’s fingers. A pause his hand on hers.  60.

dialogues.speaker: TYSON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So when we look up at the night sky, we aren’t drawn in merely for its beauty...we’re drawn in because whether we know it or not, we are all part of this universe, we are all in this universe, but more importantly, the universe is in uS... Natasha reciprocates at last. She pulls her fingers aroun his and their hands intertwine. The tension building...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights are up. Daniel’s still blown away by what they just saw. Tasha’s distant. Both of them remain in their seats.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: That was...really something. Tasha doesn’t hear him. She checks the time on her phone again: 1:01 PM. She slides her hand away from Daniel's.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did I say something wrong?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: No, it’s not you. Well, maybe it is...Don’t you think it’s weird that we've spent so much time together today? I mean, we just met. We’re practically strangers.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Honestly, I don’t think it’s weird at all. Plus, you’ve met my family...we’re definitely out of the stranger zone. Natasha softens. At ease.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Yeah, I guess. It’s just a lot to take in.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I don’t know...I just feel connected to you. A beat. Natasha’s belly growls. Their laughter relieves t romantic tension.  61.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You like Korean food?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music plays as Daniel and Tasha make their way through th densely packed streets of Koreatown. Neon signs in Korean street vendors, bicycles, and the smell of delicious food wafting in the air. Natasha sees Korean people exiting a building dragging bi suitcases. She SIGHS, the weight of the world on her shoulders. Daniel notices. She brushes it off, moving on the street. They take a quick SELFIE together as the musi ends.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: So how come you call yourself Korean? Weren’t you born here?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: People always ask where I’m from. I used to say here, but then they ask where are you really from, and then I say Korea.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: I don’t think you should say you’re from Korea.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Because it’s not true. You’re from here.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I love how simple this is for you.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Well, your solution to everything is to tell the truth. I struggle with my identity and you tell me just to say what’s true.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Why not? It’s not up to you to help other people fit you into a box.  62.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Do people do it to you?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Yeah, except I’m really not from here. We left Jamaica when I was eight. The first time I saw snow, I was in homeroom and I was so amazed I stood up to stare at it.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Oh no.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Oh yes.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Did the other kids--

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Yep. It wasn’t pretty. (shrugs) But eventually this became home. I love it here. I could stay in New York for the rest of my life.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Well, you should. Natasha deflects.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Well I’m not going to be around much longer... You know, if I don’t get some food soon. Where are we going again? Daniel stops in his tracks. Tasha follows his lead.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Turn around. The pair stand at a nondescript doorway. Confused, Tasha looks to Daniel.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Trust me. He takes her hand and they head inside, the sound of peop greeting them in Korean “Annyeonghaseyo” echoes.  63.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daniel and Tasha sit at a booth in a small hole-in-the-wa joint. Tasha looks over the menu.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: I’1l eat whatever you tell me to. Daniel rings the little bell attached to the table and a WAITRESS appears almost instantly. She gives Natasha a qu look, turns to Daniel.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: (in Korean) How can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: (in Korean) We'll have two seafood soon dubu, kalbi, and pa jun. The waitress nods and then walks off.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: There’s a bell?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Awesome, right? It takes all the mystery out of food service. When will my waiter appear? When will I get the check?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Do American restaurants know about this? Bells should be mandatory. Daniel laughs. NATASHA (CONT’D) No, I changed my mind. Can you imagine some jerk just leaning on the bell demanding ketchup? The Waitress returns and places the soup and two uncooked eggs on the table. She tosses paper-clad spoons and chopsticks into the center of the table. NATASHA (CONT’D) Oh, can I have a fork, please? The Waitress gives her a disapproving look, then walks of  64. NATASHA (CONT’D) Does this mean she’s not going to bring me a fork? Daniel laughs.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Don’t worry about her. Try this... Daniel pulls the soup bowl towards him.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is soon dubu. Tasha watches as he cracks the egg into the soup. She doe the same, then dips her spoon in and takes a bite.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Mmm. It’s delicious. Daniel smiles as Tasha does a little happy dance. He watc her eat, amused. A stream of traffic flowing through a do in the rear of the restaurant catches Tasha’s eye. NATASHA (CONT’D) What’s going on back there? This some kind of Korean mafia joint?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Oh, no. That’s the norebang. (off her look) Korean karaoke.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Then why don’t I hear any music?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: They have private rooms. Koreans are all about embarrassing themselves in private. A beat, then a mischievous look comes over Daniel’s face.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Why are you looking at me like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small, dimly lit room. Plush, red leather couches. A la square coffee table sits in front of the couch. On it, a microphone and a remote. Next to the door there’s a large  65. Daniel pours over the thick song book, he’s been flipping a while, agonizing over it. Natasha watches him.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Just choose a song.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: This is norebang. You don’t choose a song. A song chooses you.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: How poetic.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: I don’t know, most poems I’ve read are about three things: love, sex, or the stars. You poets are obsessed with stars. Falling stars. Shooting stars. Dying stars.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Stars are important.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Sure, but why not more poems about the sun? The sun is also a star and it’s the most important one. That alone should be worth a poem or two.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Being the most important star doesn’t make it the most poetic. Who wants to write about something so domineering? I’d rather ruminate on the romantic underdogs that play in the night sky.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Domineering? You’ve got it all wrong. The sun is a benevolent star. A giver...it’s also our greatest symbol of hope.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: How’s that?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: The brightest stars that we see at night are often the light from stars that have already died. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's sad, really. But the sun is different. Everyday it brings energy and life and hope to us. Without it, we’d all be lost. I think that’s something worth writing about.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Hope, huh? I never pegged you to believe in something as intangible as hope.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Just a manner of speech. It only means that something is possible. The sun makes everything on earth possible.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: You know what? You’re right. I will only write poems about the sun from now on...

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: And sex. Natasha rolls her eyes. He winks. Then starts flipping through the book. He pulls the rubber hand from his hair tosses it on the table. Tasha tries not to stare.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Are you a good singer?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Not gonna lie. I am kinda good. He grabs the remote to key in his song choice. Tasha smil The music starts and Daniel slowly settles into a dramati slump: feet planted wide, hair obscuring his bowed head a microphone held high in the air, ready to rock. The opening chords of “Kiss” by Prince fill the room. He a hand over his heart and croons the first verse. It’s Magnetic. As the song unfolds he embodies Princes’ sexual power in a completely fun and charming performance. As Daniel’s sings, Tasha’s imagination takes over. BEGIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Daniel and Tasha months down the road: lying in bed together laughing and eating cookies, Daniel playing Socc with Tasha’s brother, Daniel and Tasha wandering Ellis Is together holding hands. And then years down the road, Dan on one knee holding a ring out to a glowing Tasha. Walkin down the aisle, cooking breakfast pregnant, pushing a stroller down the streets of New York arm and arm. The fantasy is of a whole life with Daniel, a beautiful life. Daniel leans in while the songs plays without him and a cheesy guide track keeps crooning. They kiss. IN the midd of the cheesiest and most epic tiny room in the universe. ON CELL SCREEN: MEETING WITH FITZGERALD IN 30 MINUTES. She pulls away and stares intently at the message. It fil her with panic and dread. She’s not going to marry anyone She’s not going to have kids with Daniel. This is all a s Her life is over, not starting. Daniel see her shift in attitude.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Everything okay? Tasha stares at him with fear and protective anger in her eyes. She almost whispers.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: I gotta go. She then bolts out of the room. Tasha runs down the crazy hallways filled with colored li and crazy patterns. Neon flashing in her face as she well with tears.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Hey - what are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. I gotta go.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Woah! Wait! What are you sorry for?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: I just have to go. This all has to stop Daniel. Daniel chases her down the hall and she starts to run har when she eyes a door at the end of a long hallway. She sl into the door at full speed.  68.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tasha and Daniel squint and shield their eyes as they cra out into the sunlight.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: God, it’s bright out.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Back to reality. With tears still in her eyes Tasha strides down the sidew clearly to get away from everything.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Wait, what just happened?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Nothing happened.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Bullshit. You’re acting completely different. What changed?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Nothing’s changed. Daniel catches up to her and Tasha looks away.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: What are you so afraid of?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: There’s something real here. I know you feel it too.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Oh, you know how I feel? Do you? You don’t know shit Daniel.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: What’s your problem?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: This. You and me. This thing. Well this can’t happen. It’s over ok.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Hey don’t I have a say in this. I know there's something here.  69. Natasha leans in and speaks low, with intesity.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Oh, well do you know that I’m not a citizen? Huh? So you know that my family is being deported tomorrow? Huh do you know that? Do you know that all this - whatever it is. It NOT meant to be. Do you know that part? Daniel stares, silent. Totally blindsided.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: What? You’re leaving the country? Why didn’t you tell me. It’s like this is all a lie?!

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: I didn't lie to you. I just didn’t tell you everything.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I postponed my appointment because of you!

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: I didn't ask you to do that.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: But you didn’t say you’d be living in another country in less than twenty-four hours, either.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: It wasn’t your business.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: And it is now?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Look, Daniel. I told you not to fall for me, okay? I tried.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: No, here’s how you try. You open your mouth and you say the truth. Just say, “Daniel, I’m leaving the country.” “Daniel, don’t fall in love with me.”

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: You think a few kisses mean something?  70.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I think those kisses did.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Lets just end this. You have your plans and I have mine.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Sure. Whatever. I get it. Just like that. OK, Have a nice life. Daniel grabs his jacket and strides away. Tasha watches h go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daniel walks into the store visibly upset. His dad’s busy with a customer. Charlie’s face goes into a full asshole smirk as he sees Daniel is alone.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Where's your girlfriend? She dump you already?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Fuck you, Charlie. Charlie stops smirking, takes a good look at Daniel, noti his tie and jacket are missing. Shirt untucked.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Why. Are. You. Here. Little. Brother. Shouldn’t you be interviewing for Second Best School today? A beat. Daniel stares at Charlie, disgusted.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Why are you such an asshole? Seriously. What’d I ever do to you?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Is that what you came back for? To whine about me being mean to you?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: So you don’t have an answer? That’s just the way you’re made?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: That’s right. I’m stronger. And smarter. And better than you.  71. Daniel glares at his brother, anger building.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: If you’re so smart, what are you doing back here, Charlie? Big fish, small pond syndrome? Were you just a tiny douchebag fish at BU? Charlie clenches his fists. He gets right in Daniel’s fac

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You want to know why I don’t like you? Because you’re just like them. You and your mandu and perfect Korean. We’re not even from the goddamned country!

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Wait. You’re mad because I like dumplings and I speak Korean? That’s your beef? Charlie steps closer, gets in his face.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No, my problem is you don’t have a spine. You’ve always done what they’ve told you to. You’re their little golden boy. It’s pathetic.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Wow. I’m not even angry at you anymore. I just feel sorry for you. Charlie sees the pity in Daniel’s face. He grabs Daniel b the collar.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Fuck you. You think anybody’s gonna care about that shit at Yale? (then, smirking) What? You think you’re cool now because you brought some black girl in here-- Daniel PUNCHES Charlie in the eye socket, then recoils fr the pain in his hand. Charlie stumbles back. Charlie’s face turns from pain to surprise to rage. He punches Daniel in the stomach, then keeps coming. Daniel tries to block his face, but it’s no use. Charlie’s fist splits Daniel’s lip.  72. He rears back, ready to deliver another blow, but Daniel blocks his face and knees Charlie in the groin. Hard. Cha falls to the ground in agony. Their dad runs over.

dialogues.speaker: DAE
dialogues.text: (in Korean) What’s going on here? Their father eyes Daniel’s disheveled clothes and busted

dialogues.speaker: DAE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Get some ice for your lip. He turns to Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: DAE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You hit your little brother? That's what you learn from America? To hit your family? Daniel gets up and goes to the--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grabs a coke and presses it against his lip. He sits on t floor with his back against the door, breathing heavy. Lo to a mirror on the wall. A KNOCK on the door.

dialogues.speaker: DAE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Daniel, come out here now. Daniel puts the can back in the fridge and tucks his shir in. He opens the door. His father is right there.

dialogues.speaker: DAE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t care what your brother says. The only thing that matters is you go to school, you become a doctor, you be successful. You find a nice girl and have children and you have the American Dream. You don’t throw your future away for temporary things you only want right now.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: But Appa, what if I don’t want the same things you want? His father holds up his hand, silencing him.  73.

dialogues.speaker: DAE
dialogues.text: Doesn’t matter what you want. If you don’t go to Yale and become a doctor, then you’re on your own. A standoff. They hold eye contact. Neither budging. Finally Daniel grabs his crumpled suit jacket, throws it and marches out the door. Busted lip and all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hannah greets Tasha as she enters.

dialogues.speaker: HANNAH
dialogues.text: Perfect timing, Miss Kingsley. Follow me, please. Hannah leads Tasha into the back office, knocks lightly o the door. JEREMY FITZGERALD, 50s, opens the door, a small bandage above his eyebrow and another around his wrist.

dialogues.speaker: HANNAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jeremy, Tasha Kingsley.

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: Come on in. Jeremy smiles warmly at Tasha. Tasha enters hesitantly.

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Tasha) Sit, sit, sit, sit. Sorry for the delay. I reviewed your file. Please, tell me how this all came to pass.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: I’m not sure where to begin... Fitzgerald leans in.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: +..So I start with the night my father ruined our lives. INT. NATASHA’S APARTMENT - FLASHBACK - NIGHT Tasha, Peter and Mrs. Kingsley sit around the small kitch table as Mr. Kingsley clears the Chinese take out and pul an envelope out of his pocket.  74.

dialogues.speaker: MR. KINGSLEY
dialogues.text: My family. Please do me the very great honor of coming to see me perform the role of Walter Lee Younger in the Village Troupe’s production of “A Raisin in the Sun.” He pulls out three tickets and proudly hands them out. Bu Mrs. Kingsley doesn’t take hers.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. KINGSLEY
dialogues.text: You and your foolishness. You can keep your ticket. I’m not going anywhere. Mrs. Kingsley storms out. A beat later a DOOR SLAMS down hall. Peter slumps in his chair.

dialogues.speaker: MR. KINGSLEY
dialogues.text: Don’t worry ‘bout your mother. She don’t mean it, man.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But she did mean it. She didn’t go with us. Said it was a waste of her hard-earned money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tasha and Peter sit front row with an empty seat between them. Stare up at the stage.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I want to be able to say that my father was not good. That his talents were only mediocre. Mediocre would explain all the years of rejection... ON STAGE Mr. Kingsley gives a command performance. The audience, including his children, are entranced.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But he was excellent. Transcendent. He belonged on that stage more than he’s ever belonged with us. LATER - The actors bow, with Mr. Kingsley center stage, soaking it all in.  75.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I’ve never seen him happier. And I’m certain he will never be that happy again. LATER STILL - Mr. Kingsley stands center stage, staring o into the empty theater - save for Tasha and Peter. Peter breaks his father’s trance.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You ready, Pops? Mr. Kingsley looks down at them with far-away eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MR. KINGSLEY
dialogues.text: You children go on ahead. I’1l see you later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Kingsley drinks with his cast mates. They down shot a shot, enjoying the evening.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So instead of coming with us, he went out drinking with his “fellow actors.” Mr. Kingsley finally downs his last drink and stumbles to the exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: QUICK CUTS: Mr. Kingsley drives down the street recklessl POLICE CAR turns the sirens on and pulls behind him. On Mr. Kingsley’s face. Shit. He knows he messed up.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And though he only had three beers, those three beers were enough to change everything. The POLICE OFFICER approaches the window and asks for lic and registration.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: In all the time he’d been here, he'd never had one run in with the law. But here he was, face to face with cops, without the proper paperwork to show.  76.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fitzgerald’s still listening. Now puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: Can’t believe he’d get behind the wheel like that with so much at stake.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: I don’t think he was thinking about anything but how happy... how free he was in that moment. On Tasha’s face. There’s more to it than she’s saying.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: That was part of it, but not the whole story... INT. NATASHA’S APARTMENT - FLASHBACK - NIGHT Tasha leans her ear against the door of her parents’ bedr INSIDE Mr. and Mrs. Kingsley argue.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. KINGSLEY
dialogues.text: When we met you said all my dreams would come true. You remember that, Kingsley? You’re a good actor because you make me believe all the pretty things you say.

dialogues.speaker: MR. KINGSLEY
dialogues.text: I’m tired of your dreams. What ‘bout mine? If it wasn’t for you and the children, my life would be better. If it wasn’t for you and the children I would have all the things I want. I’d be doing the thing God put me on this earth to do. IN THE HALLWAY - Tasha slumps down as her father’s words her heart.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But I don’t tell Fitzgerald that part-- that we are my father’s greatest regret because we got in the way of his dreams.  77.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fitzgerald sits silent, hands steepled as he thinks.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I wonder how many stories like mine has Fitzgerald’s heard over the years. How many hopeless cases he’s had to sit through... Fitzgerald looks over one of the forms then gets a yellow legal pad out of his desk drawer, then jots something dow Then he sits in silence for a long beat. His expression v hard to read. Tasha stares at him, nervously.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Each moment of silence is soul crushing. I knew I shouldn’t have listened to Hannah. Shouldn’t have gotten my hopes up... Then finally--

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: Miss Kingsley--

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: It’s okay. I know I’m out of options. Thank you for your time. Tasha moves to get up. But Fitzgerald waves her back down

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: You’re never out of options.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: What do you mean? Are you saying you can fix this?

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: I’m going to go see a judge friend of mine. He’ll be able to get the Voluntary Removal reversed so at least you don’t have to leave tomorrow. After that we can file an appeal with the BIA-the Board of Immigration Appeals... (checks his watch) Give me a couple of hours. I can make this happen. Just need to get the judge to file by six o'clock. Tasha’s taken aback.  78.

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I‘1l call you when it’s all sorted out.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: But you think you can sort it out?

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: Yes. I’ve done it many, many times before. You'll be fine. He smiles at her confidently. Tasha’s eyes light up. She throws her arms around him in a big, impromptu bear hug.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Thank you. You have no idea how much this means to me. My family.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I should call my parents and tell them, but right now, all I can think about is Daniel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daniel sits at an empty booth. Omar sees him and walks ov looks him up and down.

dialogues.speaker: OMAR
dialogues.text: Dude, what the hell happened to you? Did you get robbed?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: What? (then realizing) I got into a fight. With Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: OMAR
dialogues.text: Oooh! Finally! That dick’s had it coming for a good ten years... (a beat) How'd your interview go?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Postponed it. For Tasha.

dialogues.speaker: OMAR
dialogues.text: Are you insane?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Yes. Probably. But then we got into it and now I’ve lost her, too--  79. Omar sits down across from Daniel.

dialogues.speaker: OMAR
dialogues.text: You’re such a drama queen. It’s just a girl, man. There’s other girls.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: No. Not like her. I didn’t even get her number.

dialogues.speaker: OMAR
dialogues.text: So Facebook her.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I don’t know her last name.

dialogues.speaker: OMAR
dialogues.text: So? If it’s in the stars, nothing can stop it. Even your clumsy, no- game-having ass, can’t fuck up this good thing if it really was sent down from Zeus or whoever.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Am I supposed to sit here and wait for her to walk in the door?

dialogues.speaker: OMAR
dialogues.text: No, but you can retrace your steps. Or, better yet, Do you know where she might be headed? Daniel thinks. Then jumps up from the booth and runs out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tasha walks down the platform and onto the UPTOWN train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daniel sprints down the platform, barely making it onto t DOWNTOWN train as the door closes. We pull out to REVEAL Tasha and Daniel are in the same pl heading in opposite directions. Natasha’s on the UPTOWN TRAIN, back to the platform. Dani on the DOWNTOWN TRAIN facing it. The trains start moving in opposite directions.  80.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bell on the door CHIMES with happy optimism as Tasha steps in. Looks behind the counter and sees Charlie on hi phone. He barely looks up as Tasha approaches the counter

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Hey. Charlie finishes with his text and finally looks up. His is red and swollen. NATASHA (CONT’D) Wow! That thing’s gonna be black and blue by morning. Charlie raises his hand and touches his eye self-consciou His knuckles are bruised too.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Daniel’s not here.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: I know. I was hoping you could help me find him. Do you have his cell phone number? Charlie leans back in his chair.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You two get into a fight?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Do you have it or not? He flips his phone end over end.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What’s your deal? You got a Korean boy fetish or something?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Charlie. Please. I have something important I need to tell him.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Tell me why I should. Tasha thinks...

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Well, think about how much trouble I’ll cause for your brother. He’s in love with me. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You give me his number, he chases after me and you can just sit back and enjoy the show while your parents freak out on him. It’s like you said-- it’1l take all the heat off you. Charlie throws his head back and laughs.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: That's a pretty decent pitch. Charlie takes a beat, considers this. Then he pulls up th number and shows it to a surprised Tasha.

dialogues.speaker: AS NECESSARY
dialogues.text: Daniel stares down at a number he doesn’t recognize on hi phone. Answers it anyway.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Is this Daniel?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Natasha?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Yes, it’s me. Your brother gave me your number.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Charlie? Yeah, right. Who is this?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Daniel, it’s me. It’s really me. Daniel stands up, moving away from Omar.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Why are you calling me?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Just give me a chance to explain. Daniel is still hurt from their fight.  82.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Are you sure I’m not a not a waste of time?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Come on, Daniel. It’s complicated. Meet me somewhere. Please? Off Daniel’s look, he’s softening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Montage of Natasha and Daniel walking and talking through city. Natasha is explaining her deportation situation to Daniel. Quickly cut, this scene is set to a bittersweet musical theme. Daniel digests her story.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: And I thought my home life was complicated. What’s the good news again?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Oh, a new lawyer thinks he can get the order reversed...

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Does that mean--

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: I might not have to leave tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: (beaming) What? Seriously? No way! Daniel LIFTS Tasha off her feet and SPINS her around.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: He wasn’t a hundred-percent sure, but there’s a chance.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I can’t believe it. Daniel holds Tasha. Their eyes meet. Daniel tilts forward Before he can kiss her, she pulls away with excitement.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: I got an idea. She takes his hand and leads him towards...  83.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The little Roosevelt Island tram car glides over the East River and into the station. Natasha and Daniel buy ticket

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tram is empty but for Daniel and Tasha. All of New Yo is in view. A breathtaking panorama.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Last time I was on this thing was in second grade. And there was an old guy who smelled like tuna fish.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: I hate tuna fish.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Right? Now I’ve got an idea. Daniel scrolls a playlist on his phone and presses PLAY. hear PURPLE RAIN by Prince: Tasha smiles. He’s cute. His striking looks illuminated b the setting sun. She looks awkwardly at the floor, then o the window, laughs. He takes her hand, pulls her close. They dance slowly in the middle of the sky. The MUSIC PLA as We SWEEP around the car, all of New York City glimmeri around them.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Is it gonna hurt if I kiss you?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: It'll be a good pain. She pulls him in. Then, a kiss like no other. Sparks fly. Tasha opens her eyes. She pulls back.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: All our kisses aren’t going to be like that are they?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: You know. Insane. Daniel smiles.  84.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I don’t know... maybe we should try it again and see. They kiss again, holding one another as the music continu to play. The entire city lit up at night. Lights twinklin the surrounding skyscrapers, like stars in the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Manhattan glows across the East River. Tasha rests on Daniel’s chest, wrapped in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: It's getting late. Are your parents going to be worried about you?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: They're okay...told them I was with Bev tonight. What about your parents?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I’1l deal with them later. Tonight’s about us.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: In that case...got any more of those questions for me?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: You’re not in love with me yet?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: (smiles) Nope.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Don’t worry. We’ve got time now. Tasha nuzzles further into Daniel’s warm body.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How about the dinner guest question?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: You mean who I'd invite?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Yup.  85.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Easy. Carl Sagan.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: You'd like him...a scientist anda writer. It was almost romantic how much he loved the universe. (then) People think science is so cold, but it isn’t true. It actually makes you appreciate your life.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Meaning... Tasha smiles, shifts her gaze upward to the heavens.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Think about it...the universe is 99.99999% empty space. Nothing but rocks and burning stars spread out over a billion galaxies--and yet here we are, the two of us together, looking out at the universe. We won the cosmic lottery just by being born...the time we have on this earth is extraordinary. It’s up to us to make the most of it. Daniel is speechless. Charmed by her words. They lock eye

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I want to make the most of everything...with you. Daniel’s instincts take over. He kisses her. A SHOOTING STAR begins a TIMELAPSE of the night sky, endi as the sun rises above the New York skyline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tasha’s already up, watching the sunrise. Daniel’s ALARM off, waking him. Tasha greets him with a kiss.

dialogues.speaker: TASHA
dialogues.text: Good morning.  86.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I could get used to waking up like this. How long have you been up?

dialogues.speaker: TASHA
dialogues.text: I wanted to see the sunrise. It’s a perfect morning. Daniel joins her. They look out to the city together. A b Then, a hint of dread on Daniel’s face.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I'd better go. My interview’s in an hour.

dialogues.speaker: TASHA
dialogues.text: I’m coming with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daniel hesitates at the entryway before going inside.

dialogues.speaker: TASHA
dialogues.text: Wait? What are we doing here?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: My interview’s in the same building as your appointment. Looks like we've traded places.

dialogues.speaker: TASHA
dialogues.text: Really? What are the odds?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I keep telling you--

dialogues.speaker: TASHA
dialogues.text: Don’t say it.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I won't rub it in this time. Will you wait for me? Of course she will. Tasha steps closer, straightens his t for him. Daniel dusts off his pants.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How do I look?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Like a poet in a suit. Tasha pecks him on the cheek.  87. NATASHA (CONT’D) You got this! Daniel takes a deep breath and heads in. Natasha hangs ba

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daniel taps on the door. Silence. He tries the handle. Locked. Daniel SIGHS. Almost relieved. Then...

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Daniel Bae. Daniel presses his ear to the door. Checks the handle aga

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: (into the door) Hello?

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Behind you. PULL BACK to REVEAL Fitzgerald, watching Daniel talking t the door. Daniel looks back and straightens up.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Oh--Umm... Hi.

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: Jeremy Fitzgerald.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Mr. Fitzgerald. It’s nice to meet you. Fitzgerald unlocks the door and opens it wide.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sorry...I thought--

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: No, I’m late. Come in and have a seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fitzgerald looks over Daniel’s application as he moves to desk. Daniel sits and sees a file on the desk. “Natasha Kingsley.” Daniel stares, shocked.  88.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Are you an immigration lawyer?

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: I am. Why?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I think I know one of your clients. Daniel picks up Tasha’s file and Fitzgerald immediately snatches it back.

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: Don’t touch that. It’s privileged. He pulls it as far away from Daniel as possible.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Sorry. You...you saved my life.

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I met her-- Natasha-- yesterday. Just a handful of hours ago she said she was being deported, but then she met with you and you did your lawyer magic, and now she’s going to stay.

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: And how did that save your life?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: She’s The One.

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: Didn't you say you just met her yesterday?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Yup.

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: And you know she’s the one? Fitzgerald stares at Daniel skeptically.

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why are you here?  89.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Um, I’m here for my admission interview?

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: No, really. Why are you here? You obviously don’t care about this interview. You postponed it and now you show up here in wrinkled clothes, looking like you’ve been in a brawl. It’s a serious question. Why did you come here? Daniel takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Honestly? My parents made me. So I guess I have to be here.

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: No, you don’t. You can just get up and walk out that door.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I owe it to my parents.

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: (sighs) My parents are immigrants. They work all the time so my brother and I can have the American Dream. Nowhere in the American Dream does it say you can skip college and become a starving artist.

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: It says whatever you want it to.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Not in my family it doesn’t. If I don’t do this, I get cut off. No funds for college. No nothing.

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: Would they really do that? Daniel FLASHES BACK to the image of HIS FATHER’S FACE as gives Daniel the ultimatum.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Yes. He would.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I guess you have to be sure this artist life is worth it.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Haven't you ever done something only because you’re obligated to? Just because you made a promise? Fitzgerald’s eyes drift away.

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: Meeting your obligations is the definition of adulthood, kid. And today, I have to make a call that I didn’t want to have to make. He pulls out Natasha’s file.

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I couldn’t do it.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Do what?

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: Stop her deportation. (off Daniel’s look) Your Natasha...she’s going to be deported today. I’m sorry, kid. Daniel stares down at the file, incredulous.

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I tried everything--

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: You didn’t try hard enough.

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: Listen, I know you’re upset.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: It’s not her fault her dad messed up. She’s been here all of her life. America is her home!

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: I wish there was something I could do. I’m planning on calling her after you and I are done here.  91.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: You’re just going to call her and tell her over the phone?

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: Does it matter how she hears it?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Of course it matters. I don’t want her to have her heart broken by someone she barely knows. Daniel walks out, into the empty reception area. Fitzgera follows.

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: So that’s it? No more interview?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: You said it yourself. I don’t really care about Yale.

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: Look, Daniel, Yale’s a big deal. Going there could open a lot of doors for you. It did for me.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: And you're still not happy.

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: What’s another half an hour to finish this interview?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Time counts, Mr. Fitzgerald... But you know that already. Daniel storms off in search of Natasha.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daniel walks through the sliding glass doors. His face is grim. Tasha takes notice.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: What happened? A beat.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I really love you.  92.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Daniel, what’s wrong?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: You don’t have to say it back, but I really do. I just want you to know it. Tasha’s phone rings. It’s Fitzgerald's office.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t answer it.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: I have to--

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Please don’t. His tone alarms her. Tasha lets it go to voicemail.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: What happened in there?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: You can’t stay here... (beat, then) My interviewer was your lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Fitzgerald? Daniel nods. NATASHA (CONT’D) What did he say?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: He couldn’t get the order overturned.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: But he said he could do it! Daniel’s squeezes her hand and tries to pull her in, but Tasha pushes him away. NATASHA (CONT’D) Are you sure? Why were you even talking about me?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Your file was on his desk.  93. He grabs her hand again. Tasha pulls it back forcefully.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Stop. Just stop!

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Just tell me what he said. Exactly.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: He said the deportation order stands. You and your family have to leave. Today. Tasha sits on the edge of the fountain. Daniel joins her.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are we going to do?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: I should go home. Flight’s this afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I‘1l go with you. (off her look) I mean to your house.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: I don’t think that’s a good idea. My parents are there and I have too much to do. You’1ll just get in the way. He stands up and holds out his hand for hers.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Here’s what we’re not going to do. We are not going to argue. We are not going to pretend that this isn’t the worst thing on earth, because it is. I’m going with you to your parents’ house. I’m going to look at the place where you sleep and eat and live and wish that I’d known just a little sooner that you were right here. (beat, then) Is that okay with you? Tasha nods yes. They start walking toward the subway stat  33
INT. NATASHA’S BUILDING - HALLWAY - DAY Daniel fidgets with his suit. Tasha feigns a smile.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Should I take my jacket off? I feel like an idiot.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: You don’t have to be nervous.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I’m going to meet your parents. Now’s as good a time to be nervous as any. He unbuttons the jacket but doesn’t take it off.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: The good thing is, you can screw up all you want. You’ll probably never see them again. INT. NATASHA’S APARTMENT - CONTINUOUS 33 Tasha cautiously steps in, followed by Daniel. Peter pack suitcases as he sways to loud dancehall music.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. KINGSLEY
dialogues.text: Turn that music off. Peter does just that as Tasha’s Mom sees her.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. KINGSLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Lawd, ‘Tasha. I been calling and calling you for-- Mrs. Kingsley notices Daniel and pauses. MRS. KINGSLEY (CONT’D) Who's this?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: This is Daniel. Mrs. Kingsley zeroes in. Examines Daniel more closely.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Sorry to meet you under these circumstances, Mrs. Kingsley. Daniel shakes Mrs. Kingsley’s hand, then Peter greets him  95.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (smiling wide) ‘Tasha’s never brought a boy here before. Mrs. Kingsley waves Tasha to the side.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. KINGSLEY
dialogues.text: ‘Tasha, I need to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Is it about Daniel? Because if it is, we can just do it right here. He’s my boyfriend. Mr. Kingsley walks in as the words leave Tasha’s lips.

dialogues.speaker: MR. KINGSLEY
dialogues.text: Since when do you have a boyfriend? That's what you been doing all day and night instead of helping your family pack up?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: No. What I was doing was trying to fix your mistakes.

dialogues.speaker: MR. KINGSLEY
dialogues.text: It don't look nothing like that to me. (turns to Daniel) You know the situation? Daniel nods. MR. KINGSLEY (CONT’D) Then you know that now’s not the time for strangers to be here.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: He’s not a stranger. He’s my guest.

dialogues.speaker: MR. KINGSLEY
dialogues.text: And this is my house--

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Was your house. You weren’t responsible enough of a father to keep it, remember? Or maybe you couldn’t handle the responsibility of being a father at all...

dialogues.speaker: MR. KINGSLEY
dialogues.text: What’s that supposed to mean?  96.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: I heard what you told mom after the play--

dialogues.speaker: MRS. KINGSLEY
dialogues.text: Baby. There’s no point in rehashing all this now.

dialogues.speaker: MR. KINGSLEY
dialogues.text: No, man. No, man. I want hear what she has to say to me. Just as father and daughter square off. Daniel interjects

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Tasha, you don’t have to-- Mr. Kingsley pushes Daniel back.

dialogues.speaker: MR. KINGSLEY
dialogues.text: Say what you have to say, Tasha! Tasha looks at Daniel, she wants to do this. She steps up her father.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: I heard what you said about me and Peter... That we were your greatest regrets. How could you say that about your own children? The steam comes out of Mr. Kingsley’s engine. He searches futilely for words... NATASHA (CONT’D) I’m sorry that life didn’t give you all the things you wanted.

dialogues.speaker: MR. KINGSLEY
dialogues.text: I didn’t mean it ‘Tasha. It was just talk. All of it was just-- She holds up her hand to stop him. Tears pool in Mr. Kingsley’s eyes.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Maybe you were right. Maybe you weren’t meant to have us. Maybe you really were cheated.

dialogues.speaker: MR. KINGSLEY
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) Was just talk ‘Tasha. I really didn’t mean nothing by it.  97.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: It doesn’t matter if you meant it or not. Hearing you say those words spoiled all the good memories I did have of us. Made me wonder, did you regret my existence when we were watching cricket matches together? Eating mint chocolate chip ice cream after school? What about the day I was born? Tears stream from Natasha’s face. Daniel holds her. She p free from him, continuing. NATASHA (CONT’D) But I decided, you don’t get to regret us. People make mistakes all the time. Small ones, like getting in the wrong checkout line. And big ones like giving up... I saw the play. That night, on stage you were incredible. But in real life, all you’ve done is quit on your family. Leaving the rest of us to pick up where you left off. Mrs. Kingsley’s crying now too. Peter walks into her arms a hug.

dialogues.speaker: MR. KINGSLEY
dialogues.text: ‘Tasha, I’m sorry. You should have never heard those words from my mouth. When we came here, it was supposed to be different... but America has never been what they said it was gonna be for me. I can’t stand seeing your mother work her fingers to the bone day in and day out anymore than I can stand the holes in your brother's sneakers. We’re immigrants, Tasha. How can I be a man when the rest of the world says that I am not? Tasha wipes her brother’s face. Comforts him. Replies.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: You decide who you are, that’s how. That’s why we came here, not for handouts, but to make our own lives. Mr. Kingsley holds his head in his hands. Ashamed. Tasha approaches, gently laying a hand on his shoulder.  34 98. NATASHA (CONT’D) Dad, I know what it cost you to bring us here. But just because it got hard, doesn’t mean we don’t still need you. When we get to Jamaica, you can’t give up. You can be a father. A husband. And an actor all at once. It’s up to you. She hugs him. Mrs. Kingsley and Peter join in.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It wasn't exactly the ending I was hoping for this morning, but at least we were on our way to being a family again. Tasha sniffs, then motions for Daniel. Together as one, t embrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter looks out from the back of a cab as it drives off w Tasha’s family. On the curb, a CABBIE loads Tasha’s suitc into the trunk of another cab. Tasha finishes a FACETIME Bev as Daniel climbs into the backseat.

dialogues.speaker: BEV, (ON THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: I’m booking my flight now! Christmas in Jamaica is a thing, right?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA, (ON THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: (laughs) Yes, I believe so. (beat) I’m so sorry, Bev. It all happened so fast. The cabbie gets inside the car. NATASHA (CONT’D) I have to go. I’1l call you soon as I land. Love you. Tasha hangs up, then gets in the cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Natasha looks out the window, soaking up her Bronx neighborhood one final time. Then she lays her head on Daniel’s shoulder.  99.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Do you think we would've worked out if I stayed?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: No question. Do you?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Yes. Daniel smiles. NATASHA (CONT’D) How hard would it have been for your parents?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: It would take them a long time. Longer for my dad. I don’t think they’d have come to our wedding.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: I have something to tell you.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: You shouldn’t go to Yale and be a doctor if your heart’s not in it. If you want to be a poet and write your heart out, do that. There’s still time.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: What about doing the practical thing?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Practicality is overrated.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Does that mean you don’t want to be a data scientist anymore?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Maybe not. You got me thinking. It’d be nice to do something I’m actually passionate about, like study the stars. Daniel turns to her, surprised.  100.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: What a difference a day makes. They're silent for a long beat.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: So, how many more questions do we have left? He takes out his phone. He laughs.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Just one. And we still have to stare into each other’s eyes for four minutes.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: We could do that or...we could just make out instead.

dialogues.speaker: CABBIE
dialogues.text: You guys know I can hear you, right? (through the rearview mirror) I can see you too. Tasha and Daniel join in.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Okay, last question. Of all the people in your family, whose death would you find the most disturbing, and why?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: My dad.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Why him?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Because he’s not done yet. What about you?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Yours.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: I’m not your family, though.  101.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Yes, you are. In some other universe maybe we're married, with two kids, or maybe two cats.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: You always find the right words. (beat) You’1ll make a great poet. Daniel takes this in. The cab pulls to the curb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tasha and Daniel stand at the curb, trying their best to it together. Prince’s “I Would Die For You” starts playin the radio inside the cab.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: You hear that? Tasha cracks a somber smile.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Three times in one day...what are the odds? Daniel winks. Tasha softens.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So...are you ready for the finale? Daniel sets his phone timer for FOUR MINUTES then takes b Natasha’s hands in his.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m not sure if we’re supposed to hold hands during this part but -- why not. The clock runs. They stare into each other’s eyes, giggli little at first. Tasha looks away but Daniel squeezes her hands just enough to get her to focus. As she stares in h eyes...

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Daniel believes this is fate... that everything aligned for us to be in the right place at just the right time. I don’t know that this is fate. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But I do know that a lot of events had to transpire for us to be standing here, right now, in the middle of this vast universe. That’s amazing. They continue to stare, less self-conscious. Their smiles drift away as they catalog each other’s face. Tasha reliv all the moments that led them here:

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Because if I hadn't been late to my appointment, I wouldn’t have met Lester Barnes. And if he hadn’t said the word ‘irie,’ I wouldn’t have had a meltdown. And if I hadn’t had my meltdown, I wouldn’t have eventually met Daniel. As she speaks, we see GLIMPSES of the day.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And if I hadn’t met Daniel, I may have never known this feeling that’s taking over me right now. This feeling that can only be-- The phone timer BUZZES, bringing Tasha BACK TO REALITY.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Love. (beat, then) I love you, Daniel Bae.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I guess the questionnaire worked. Tasha’s phone RINGS. She looks down. It’s her mom.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You have to go... She nods. But neither one of them moves.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: I don’t know how to say goodbye. Daniel’s eyes mist.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Then don’t... On Tasha’s face, she has to.  103.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This day can’t be all there is. It just can’t-- Before he can finish, Tasha pulls him into a long, final Then she reluctantly lets him go.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Bye, Daniel. Tasha turns and walks off, leaving Daniel looking on, heartbroken, as she disappears inside the airport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daniel gets in a cab and shuts the door. Slumps in his se

dialogues.speaker: CABBIE
dialogues.text: Where to?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I don’t care. Just drive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Natasha and her family check their bags.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. KINGSLEY
dialogues.text: Get out your ID's. Tasha searches her purse, absentmindedly. Her heart still with Daniel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cab approaches two paths: one to exit the airport, th other to return to the terminals. Daniel looks back and f between the two paths. Then suddenly sits up.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Can you please circle back?

dialogues.speaker: CABBIE
dialogues.text: Did you forget something?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Something really important. The cabbie takes the terminal exit and they circle back.  104.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Natasha and her family enter the long TSA security line. CLOSE ON her ticket. ONE WAY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The taxi pulls up to Tasha’s terminal. Daniel hands the cabbie a few bucks and then takes off running.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daniel sprints through the airport, searching for Tasha. TICKETING AREA —- CONTINUOUS Daniel panting heavily, hair in his face. No Tasha. He lo up...

dialogues.speaker: ON THE DEPARTURES BOARD
dialogues.text: Countries from all over the world. He finds the flight to Jamaica. Daniel notes the gate. DARTS off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tasha and her family wait their turn in the TSA line.

dialogues.speaker: ON DANIEL
dialogues.text: Searching the crowded line for her. No Tasha. Then finall He spots a familiar AFRO in the crowd of people. He slows a brisk walk, fixes his hair, then ducks under the stretc barriers, cutting the line.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: She’s lost in her own world, head down. Forlorn. Then...

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: ‘Tasha! She turns at the sound of her name.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: His eyes go WIDE...  105. It’s TASHA! She looks on at Daniel, in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Marry me. Then you can legally stay.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Marry you? You can’t be serious. (off his look) You are.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: You love me, right? Isn’t that what you just said?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: I do, but--

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: So we'll elope and we’1ll move somewhere cheap... I’ll get a crappy job and write at night... and you can finish school and graduate with your friends and then become a data scientist or-- an astronomer! You can do whatever you want, Tasha. Just stay.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Daniel... listen. I do really love you. But we have to be smart. We’ve only known each other for a day. A day. You keep saying we're meant to be, but what if we’re not? An ANNOUNCEMENT drowns her out.

dialogues.speaker: GATE AGENT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (loudspeaker) This is the boarding call for flight 436 to Jamaica... Time’s up. Tears gather in Tasha’s eyes. She takes Daniel the hand.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Right now, this is real life. The plane waiting on the tarmac to send me and my family back to Jamaica is very real. I tried to stay... (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I tried everything and I failed, and now that’s it. I have to go. Tasha lets a single tear fall down her face. Daniel wipes off. They stand face-to-face in the security line.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I don’t want to lose you.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: What happens next is up to us. We decide our fate. There’s Facetime, emails, Skype... we'll figure it out. We’re not going to give up, okay? Tasha plants a final kiss on Daniel’s cheek, then rejoins family in the security line. Daniel looks on, distraught. INT. TASHA’S PLANE - DUSK Tasha stares out the window as the sun begins to set. Her mother pats her arm reassuringly.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. KINGSLEY
dialogues.text: It's going to be okay, Tasha. You'll see... Tasha manages a small smile. The plane ascends into the n sky. Tasha looks out the window watching the city fade.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: From up here, the city lights look like earth-bound stars. And I know one of those stars is Daniel...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daniel sits on a train, watches a plane take off. Is it Tasha’s? He takes out his notebook and starts to write.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You come to me from another world. He looks out the window as the airport fades into the distance.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (V.O., CONT'D)
dialogues.text: From beyond the stars and void of space. Transcendent. Pure. Of unimaginable beauty.  107. INT. TASHA’S PLANE - DUSK Natasha looks out the window at the city below. The plane climbs higher and higher, into the clouds.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You are the master alchemist. You light the fire of love in earth and sky in heart and soul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daniel gazes out the window at all the buildings lit up w people inside, in their homes.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Through your star... All opposites unite. More than a star. INT. TASHA’S PLANE - DUSK Natasha's face looking out at the horizon. The glow of th sun hits her face just as it sets.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You are my sun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drone shot of the little train snaking through Queens at night. The Manhattan skyline glimmers in the background.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My mom’s gonna be pissed when I get home. And that’s fine. Because this time next year, I’1l be someplace else. I don’t know where, but not here. And not Yale either. Am I making a mistake? Maybe. But it’s mine to make.

dialogues.speaker: BEDROOM
dialogues.text: SPLIT SCREEN: The two share stories of their day via SKYP

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Over the next year, we tried hard to make it work...  108.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tasha’s TEACHER hands her an exam back. It’s an “A.” Her JAMAICAN BESTIE sees the “A” and gives Tasha a smile. In bag, her phone lights up. A missed call from Daniel.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But time and distance are love's natural enemies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daniel sprints from the building, hops on his bike and pe furiously.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And the days are full.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daniel runs in, throws on his waiter apron and gets ready his shift. Nods to Omar who’s taking a dish out into the dining room. In his bag, his phone rings. A Facetime requ from Tasha that goes unanswered.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It’s not that I wanted to let her go...I had to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tasha and her NEW FRIENDS walk through a small town, havi good time. They’re surrounded by little stores and mercha selling their wares. She laughs at a CUTE BOY'S joke.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It wasn't possible for her to live in two worlds simultaneously. Heart in one place, body in another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daniel, now in his early 20's, new hair cut, still sexy, stands at the mic, visibly nervous, reading his poem.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: You are the master alchemist. You light the fire of love in earth and sky in heart and soul.  109.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I let go of Daniel to avoid being ripped apart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tasha, now in her early 20's, engages her CO-WORKERS in a passionate discussion at work.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And as more years passed, we both entered the adult world of practicalities and responsibilities... EXT. DANIEL’S APARTMENT - DAY Daniel reads a rejection letter from a publishing company He’s heartbroken.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: When my mom died, I thought of him... INT. TASHA’S APARTMENT - DAY Later, still wearing her black funeral dress, Tasha looks the norebang selfie of her and Daniel.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The magic of that day...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daniel walks in.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: +.-all the little coincidences it took to get us to meet and fall in love. Daniel peruses the aisles.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Tasha often talked about the number of events that had to go exactly right to form our universe. She’d said falling in love couldn’t compete.  110. Daniel picks up Lou Reed’s “Transformer,” smiles.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But I’ve always thought she was wrong about that...

dialogues.speaker: CHYRON
dialogues.text: A FEMALE FLIGHT ATTENDANT walks down the aisle checking o passengers. In the b.g., We SEE a pair of headphones atop BIG CURLY AFRO that’s been dyed PINK at the ends.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Maybe our Universe was just taking longer to form... We MOVE IN. It’s Natasha, sitting in the aisle seat. A LI GIRL (6) colors in her book of the COSMOS next to her. The girl meticulously details an image of a STAR with a yellow crayon. We HEAR Prince’s “Purple Rain” coming from Tasha’s headphones. The Little Girl taps Natasha’s shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE GIRL
dialogues.text: What are you listening to?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Just something I like to play when I travel. Do you want to hear it? The girl NODS. Tasha puts the headphones over her ears. Natasha HUMS along to the music. A YOUNG MAN seated in fr of them turns around. He peers back at them, his face obscured by the seat. After a verse and a chorus or so, the Little Girl gives t headphones back to Tasha.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE GIRL
dialogues.text: It’s nice, but I prefer Beyonce.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: (laughing) It reminds me of someone. The CUTEST SMILE you've ever seen from the Little Girl.  111.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE GIRL
dialogues.text: Is it a boy?

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Maybe...

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE GIRL
dialogues.text: Do you love him?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Of course she does... Tasha looks up. REVEAL Daniel Bae standing there, five ye older, staring her right in the face.

dialogues.speaker: NATASHA
dialogues.text: Daniel? Natasha smiles WIDE. Daniel smiles back. NATASHA (CONT’D) Daniel. Their eyes meet as both Tasha and Daniel keep beaming. Neither believing what they’re seeing is real. But it is. Despite the odds, this was meant to be. It was in the sta FADE OUT.
